Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TREAD MILL", "wheel", "axle"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1915", "1588", "1900"], "places": ["Carisbrooke Castle", "Isle of Wight", "South Kensington"], "descriptions": ["animal power prime mover from early times to the present, in a number of different forms, for such purposes as raising water, turning a spit, or as a means of punishment.", "represents the well-known mill at Carisbrooke Castle, Isle of Wight, as originally constructed", "is said to date from 1588, and is still in use for drawing water from the old well of the Castle.", "an embodiment of the wheel and axle mechanism.", "of oak, has lagging fastened to felloes of natural-grown timber tongued and pinned together and tied back by arms tangential to the eight-squared axle where the latter are tightened by wedges; intermediate support to the felloes is given by timbers halved on the arms.", "a chestnut baulk about 14 in. diam., has iron gudgeons 2 in. diam. revolving on cast-iron pillow blocks supported by the walls of the well-house.", "a typical piece of medi\u00e6val carpentry.", "A donkey walking inside actuates the wheel and raises a bucket of water by coiling a rope on the axle.", "There is a band brake now on the axle, but this is a modern addition; it is believed that originally the wheel was braked simply by a piece of wood held against the circumference."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12", "effective diameter of the wheel is 14\u00b76 ft.", "diameter of the axle, lagged where the rope coils on, is 21\u00b75 in.", "more lagging was put on, bringing the equivalent diameter up to 28\u00b74 in.; the mechanical advantage, allowing for the thickness of the rope, has thus been altered from 7\u00b74 : 1 to 5\u00b77 : 1.", "donkey causes the wheel to make four turns per min., i.e., it walks at the rate of 2\u00b708 miles an hour.", "wheel is allowed to rotate at about 20 turns per min.", "well is 161 ft. deep", "16 to 20 turns of the wheel, according to the level at which the water is standing, are required to bring the bucket to the surface.", "weight of the water raised is 120 lb.; taking into account the weight of the bucket, chain and rope, the h.p. is about 0.2, which is as much as a donkey is usually considered capable of doing.", "Inv. 1915-317"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This shows a very general form of machine for applying the power of a horse to the driving of light machinery, such as chaff-cutters, small pumps, etc.; but although larger gears are made to transmit the power of two or four horses, they are not much used in this country when the power required approaches that of a small steam engine.", "The machine has a pole attached to the vertical axis of a bevel wheel of 103 teeth, gearing into a bevel pinion of 12 teeth, whose rotation is transmitted by a shaft coupled by universal joints to multiplying spur gear placed outside the circular horse track.", "The multiplying gear consists of a spur wheel of 76 teeth driving a pinion of 17 teeth, to the shaft of which a pulley is attached for further transmitting the power by belting.", "The horse in going once round the track causes the pulley to make 38.3 rev., and when walking at 2.5 miles per hour in a path 25 ft. in diam., drives the pulley at 108 rev. per min."], "other": ["Scale 1: 8", "Inv. 1891-152", "Motive Power animal power; animal power"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Messrs. J. Crowley & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a small and compact form of gear patented in 1879 and intended for use with a pony.", "The slow speed of the vertical shaft turned by the animal is multiplied 30.2 times so as to give higher speed to the horizontal shaft from which machinery is to be driven.", "To the bracket that holds the pole is attached a short horizontal shaft, carrying a bevel wheel of 31 teeth and a bevel pinion of 22 teeth. The pinion gears into a horizontal bevel ring that forms part of the framing, and a bevel pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The bevel wheel gears with a bevel pinion of 22 teeth on a vertical axis in the centre, and this pinion carries gears with a pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The motion is transmitted through two Hooke's joints to the external driving pulley, a pawl gear preventing accidental rotation in the wrong direction."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-391", "1879"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A compact gear, designed for use with a pony, that increases the rotational speed of a vertical shaft to drive machinery.", "The mechanism incorporates a series of bevel gears and Hooke's joints to transmit motion to an external pulley."], "other": ["SMG"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF PONCELET'S WATER-WHEEL"], "makers": ["MM. Regnard Fr\u00e8res"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1891"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 10", "Smeaton improved the undershot wheel, but it was Gen. J. V. Poncelet who, in 1824, brought it to the high state of efficiency illustrated by the model.", "The characteristic features of his design are the backwardly curved floats and the absence of a sole plate.", "The water is projected on to the wheel buckets tangentially, at the periphery, through a sluice inclined at an angle varying between 40\u00b0 and 60\u00b0 to the horizontal, according to the diameter of the wheel and to the effective head of water.", "The sluice gate is operated by a hand-wheel, spur gear and rack.", "The buckets are proportioned so that the water enters without shock, with the velocity due to the head, and flows up the vanes, until brought to rest by gravity, when it falls, exerting downward pressure.", "The water is discharged from the floats with but little remaining forward velocity.", "In wheels of this type, however the power produced by the weight of the water is negligible compared with that due to its momentum.", "The floats are inclined on the upstream side about 30\u00b0", "the radius of the bucket is usually one-eighth the diameter of the wheel.", "Owing to its slow speed and cumbersome gearing the Poncelet wheel has been displaced by the low-fall turbine.", "The effective head of water should not exceed 5.5 ft. ; the maximum efficiency is 65 per cent."], "other": ["Inv. 1891-109", "19,386"]}

Eng."], "dates": ["1841"], "places": ["near Tavistock"], "descriptions": ["This arrangement was adopted at Wheal Friendship, near Tavistock, for mine drainage.", "The power of the wheel was transmitted through cranks at 180\u00b0, and therefore counterbalanced, to two lengths of horizontal rods coupled to bell-crank levers at the pits, where six plunger pumps were worked.", "Balance bobs arranged in pits behind the wheel were used to compensate the weight of the pump rods.", "The wheel was 51 ft. diam. by 10 ft. face and had 180 buckets built of wrought iron.", "The axle was a hollow iron casting with flanged ends, but the arms were of wood.", "The wheel made 5 revs. per min.", "In 1841 it was reported to have given an overall efficiency of 69 per cent."], "other": ["Scale 1: 24.", "Received 1857.", "Inv. 1857-225."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF PELTON OR \u201c HURDY-GURDY \u201d WATER-WHEEL"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Sandycroft Foundry and Engine Works Co.", "Engineering"], "dates": ["1890", "1737", "1827", "1874", "1878", "1920"], "places": ["California"], "descriptions": ["form of impulse turbine much used in mining districts and other situations in which a considerable head is available, as its high speed and great power render it a most convenient motor, while its extreme simplicity minimises the risk of failure.", "early form of the machine consisted of a wheel having radial floats or paddles projecting from the upon which a rapid stream of water was directed by a shoot; reversal or stop of water in such cases were both effected by moving the shoot\u2014the supply generally far exceeding the power required.", "Wheels with concave vanes were in use before the year 1737, and Poncelet in 1827 proved their superiority over those with flat vanes, but it was considerably later that in the mining districts of California the practical development of this important form of turbine was chiefly effected.", "The original \u201c miner\u2019s wheels \u201d there employed were shrouded and had vanes made as triangular prisms; they had an efficiency of about 40 per cent., but were subsequently improved by the adoption of cup-shaped vanes.", "Mr. J. Moore improved these vanes by forming them with a central wedge-shaped ridge which split the jet", "Mr. L. A. Pelton independently arrived at this double construction of cup, and to him the commercial introduction and development of the Pelton wheel is chiefly due.", "central wheel of cast iron, to the rim of which are secured twenty-eight double buckets of gunmetal 2.3 in. wide, the over-all diameter of the revolving parts being 20 in.", "shaft is carried in three bearings, near the central one of which a screen or partition would be fitted to prevent water splashing upon the belt pulley by which the power obtained is transmitted.", "supply water, which is usually brought through light pipes of sheet steel is, after passing through a sluice valve, led by a conical pipe to a removable discharge nozzle, so that by changing the nozzle the load on the wheel may be altered without seriously reducing the efficiency of the motor.", "Each bucket or cup consists of two semi-cylindrical portions, uniting in a central ridge which divides the entering water jet, so that each half slides round the inside of its cup and has its motion reversed before escaping at the opposite edge* by running the wheel at a circumferential speed slightly less than half the velocity with which the water issues from the nozzle; the whole of the energy being completely transferred from the cups, dead water is discharged from the wheel.", "To facilitate the escape of the dead water from the wheel, the buckets are given a forward inclination; the wheel must in all cases be above the level of the tail race.", "Scale 1: 4", "Lent by", "high speed and great power", "extreme simplicity"], "other": ["Scale 1: 4", "Inv. 1890-69, 19,362."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ENCLOSED PELTON MOTOR"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a small example of the impulse turbine known as the Pelton wheel.", "It is supplied with pressure water from the domestic mains or hydraulic supply, and it is enclosed in a watertight casing to render it suitable for driving small machinery within a building.", "The used water is led away by a pipe from the bottom of the case.", "The wheel runner is a cast-iron disc to which are riveted twenty Pelton buckets of bronze, which are given a backward rake to facilitate the discharge of the used water.", "The water is delivered as a horizontal jet, while the wheel while water falling on the opposite side is fixed a baffle plate to prevent the used water falling on the wheel and thereby absorbing power.", "The power developed by the motor is varied by interchanging the nozzles, of which there are three sizes, or by the removal of a box nut, or a needle regulating nozzle could be substituted.", "The stop valve should remain fully open under all circumstances.", "The wheel shaft is carried in bearings bolted to the casing, and is fitted with a pulley for belt transmission of the power given off.", "To facilitate examination of the wheel one side of the case is made removable."], "other": ["cast-iron", "bronze", "nozzles (three sizes)", "box nut", "needle regulating nozzle", "stop valve", "bearings", "pulley", "8.25 in. pitch diameter", "9.25 brake h.p.", "90 lb. pressure per sq. in.", "1,300 r.p.m.", "80 per cent.", "50 to 2,000 lb. per sq. in.", "Inv. 1903-23"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MULTIPLE NOZZLE PELTON WHEEL"], "makers": ["P. Pitman, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1903", "1902"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["When speed requirements call for a wheel of small diameter in which it is not possible to obtain sufficient power with one nozzle, two or more nozzles may be used. The jets of water are caused to impinge on the same wheel without conflict so that there is no appreciable loss of efficiency. To obtain high efficiency when there is a fluctuating supply of water, one, or two nozzles only may be employed at a time.", "The photograph shows a wheel with three nozzles made in 1902 for driving mining machinery; a feature is the low head of water under which the wheel is operating. The runner is of steel plate secured to the shaft by a cast-iron coupling. The buckets of bronze, 16 in number, are bolted to the rim, their interior surfaces being ground and polished to minimize friction losses. The supply pipe, 24 in. diam., terminates in a chamber to which are bolted three curved pipes, each fitted with a bronze nozzle independently controlled by a gate valve. The shaft runs in ring-oiled bearings mounted on cast-iron A-frames bolted to the bedplate, and to the steel plate splash housing. The power is taken off by a belt. The wheel is 5 ft. pitch diam., and under a head of 60 ft. develops 50 brake h.p. at a speed of 135 r.p.m. The efficiency varied from 75 to 80 per cent. according as one, two or three nozzles were used.", "In modern practice not more than two nozzles are employed on one wheel; if more power is required two runners are mounted on the same shaft."], "other": ["Inv. 1903-183", "mining machinery", "low head of water"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Photograph of engraving of Barker's Mill"], "makers": ["Dr. Barker", "Dr. J. T. Desaguliers", "Hero", "M. Mathon de la Cour", "James Whitelaw"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1767", "about 1743", "about A.D. 50", "1775", "1839"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["corn mill driven by a reaction turbine of the form proposed by Dr. Barker and put into practice by Dr. J. T. Desaguliers about 1743", "A similar arrangement had been used by Hero in his steam turbine or aeolipile about A.D. 50 (see No. 35)", "The machine consisted of a vertical wooden frame supporting a platform at the top, on which rested the lower and stationary millstone.", "The upper and movable millstone was attached, passed down through the middle of the frame, and its lower end fitted in a footstep bearing, mounted on a pivoted beam extending across the bottom of the frame.", "A wide tube surrounded and was fixed to the shaft, and its upper end was furnished with a funnel mouth into which the water was delivered from a supply pipe.", "The lower end of the tube terminated in two straight, horizontal arms, closed at the ends and each provided with a small orifice, through which the water issued in tangential jets which by their reaction caused the tube and shaft to rotate.", "The free end of the lower bearing lever was suspended by a long bolt from a bracket on the frame, a nut on the bolt serving to adjust the upper millstone.", "The mill in this simple form was only made in small sizes, as it entailed a central tube equal in length to the head of water available, and the mass of water in the tube and arms was carried round as useless dead weight.", "This defect was overcome by M. Mathon de la Cour, who, in 1775, proposed to deliver the water directly to the arms of the mill from the upturned end of a fixed pipe, but this improvement was not put in practice until James Whitelaw used it in 1839 (see No. 21).", "The hydraulic efficiency of the simple Barker\u2019s mill is about 66 per cent. and the brake efficiency 60 per cent., this being attained when the linear speed of the orifices is about equal to the velocity of the water due to its head.", "taken from Ferguson\u2019s \u201cMechanics,\u201d 1767"], "other": ["Inv. 1915-318", "Received 1915"]}

Stirrat"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1914", "1839", "1841"], "places": ["North Wales"], "descriptions": ["improved form of the reaction turbine", "known as the Scotch turbine", "largely used in the middle of the 19th century", "has now been superseded by more efficient types", "feature of the machine is the use of spiral arms", "water enters the centre of the turbine from the upturned end of a fixed pipe", "By these means the frictional and eddy losses are reduced and the efficiency is increased somewhat over that of the simple Barker\u2019s mill.", "two cast iron discs, 2 in. apart", "the lower one having a central orifice fitted to the end of the supply pipe so as to rotate without leakage.", "inner faces of the discs have spiral grooves formed in them, to which are fitted sheet iron plates forming the sides of the two spiral passages through which the water issues.", "These passages are of constant depth, but decrease in width from the centre to the outer edge, where they terminate in tangential orifices 0.5 in. wide.", "two discs are clamped together by four through bolts.", "vertical driving shaft is fixed to the upper disc", "end carries a bevel pinion gearing with a bevel wheel on a horizontal shaft which transmits the power to the machinery to be driven", "speed reduction being 50 to 13.", "diameter of the orifice centres is 14 in.", "supply pipe, 3.5 in. diam., is fitted with a sluice valve.", "turbine worked with a head of 15 ft.", "in use for 35 years before it was acquired for this Museum.", "Turbines of this kind were made over 9 ft. diam. and developing about 100 h.p.", "larger machines were usually fitted with self-regulating variable orifices.", "maximum hydraulic efficiency was about 75 per cent."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-898", "S.M. 676"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF FOURNEYRON\u2019S TURBINE"], "makers": ["T. B. Jordan, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1842", "1853", "1857"], "places": ["Baden"], "descriptions": ["This represents the radial outward flow turbine as constructed by Benoit Fourneyron, who completed his first machine in 1827, after having spent four years in experimenting.", "The machine consists of a vertical cylindrical chamber with a side inlet for the water, and a central pipe below through which the water passes to an annular outlet at the base of the pipe.", "This outlet is fitted with thirty guide blades which direct the water in a tangential course as it escapes.", "Surrounding this passage is a runner, keyed to a vertical shaft, and provided with vanes between which the water flows as it passes from the inner to the outer circumference, where it is finally discharged.", "A diagram model of the vanes of such a runner is seen adjoining.", "The water under pressure is discharged in a tangential direction from the fixed guides, and on passing between the vanes of the enclosing wheel has its direction of motion gradually changed until the energy of the water had been transferred to the wheel, when the water is discharged at the outer rims, dead.", "The central pipe containing the guides is carried by three screwed rods connected above by gearing, by which the pipe can be accurately raised, so as to contract the supply passage into the wheel if less than full power is required."], "other": ["Glynn\u2014Treatise on the Power of Water", "Inv. 1857-181", "182\u201419,607", "The toe of the shaft is carried in a special bearing, supplied with oil under pressure. The power given off by the shaft is transmitted by bevel gear at the upper end."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ORGAN BLOWER (working)"], "makers": ["D. Joy"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1897", "1874"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a water-pressure engine designed for working the bellows supplying air to an organ, but the cylinder in its action resembles the steam cylinder of a direct-acting steam pump. The supply of water is controlled by a valve connected with the air reservoir, so that the speed of working is automatically adjusted to the consumption of wind. The blower shown has a cylinder 5.5 in. diam. by 10 in. stroke, and is fitted with a valve gear patented by Mr. D. Joy in 1874. The piston-rod is directly attached to the bellows, but has on it a tappet which reverses the distributing slide valve on the completion of each stroke. This slide valve is of the piston type, but is in reality two valves combined in one, for by its sliding motion the valve acts as the main slide valve, while by a rotary motion through 20 deg. it acts as a plug valve. The plug is in the middle of the length of the piston slide, and by its motion lets the water to and from the ends of the chest of the piston valve, so causing the sliding motion of this valve. The rotation of the valve is performed by two inclined horns, secured to the valve-rod and moved by the tappet on the piston-rod. A simple tappet moving a single slide valve will not work at a very slow speed without assistance, and it is for this reason that some form of auxiliary valve is almost invariably introduced."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-72", "1923-503", "water-pressure engine"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Joy's patent Water Pressure Engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Sectional drawing (scale 1:12)"], "other": ["framed and glazed", "Museum Motive Power drawings", "drawings 1923"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1914", "1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is an example of the hydraulic engine for organ blowing, the valve gear of which was patented by Mr. H. Bamford in 1885. The piston-rod is connected directly with the bellows, and water is admitted to either end of the working cylinder by a piston valve. This valve is itself moved by the pressure water which is distributed by a small auxiliary slide valve driven from the piston-rod by a tappet-gear.\nThe engine has a horizontal working cylinder, with the valve chest on top. The main valve consists of four pistons, connected together and sliding in a cylindrical casing which is provided with suitable inlet and exhaust ports. The two inner pistons serve to distribute the pressure water to the end of the working cylinder, the space between them being in communication with the water inlet, while the two outer pistons are packed with cup leathers and work in the closed ends of the casing. These ends serve as cylinders, to which the pressure water is admitted alternately by the auxiliary valve, through ports in the main valve stem, so as to cause the piston valve to move from end to end. The valve stem between the two inner pistons is of rectangular section, and the necessary slide valve is applied to its upper face. Three ports are formed in this face, the outer ports leading to the ends of the main valve and the central one to the exhaust, while side lugs are formed on the auxiliary valve to keep it in place, and to serve as abutments against which the arms of a forked lever bear when moving the valve. This lever is mounted on a shaft which passes through a stuffing-box and has on its outer end a slotted lever connected with a rod which is worked backwards and forwards, through a short distance at each end of the piston stroke, by a tappet-rod fixed to an arm on the piston-rod. The tappets are adjustable so that the valve may be set to reverse the motion without shock.\nWhen the piston nears the end of its stroke, the tappet-gear carries the auxiliary valve in the same direction, thus admitting the pressure water to the opposite end of the piston valve, and driving it in the same direction so as to admit water behind the piston to drive it back. A sectioned valve chest is shown beside the engine."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-139 & 396", "S.M. 615", "Mr. H. Bamford"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Bamford Hydraulic Engine complete and with additional valve gear sectioned"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Bamford Engineering Co."], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Motive Power engines; engines"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["WATER MOTOR WITH OSCILLATING CYLINDER (working)"], "makers": ["W. H. Bailey & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["de Haag"], "dates": ["1894"], "places": ["mine workings", "mine sump"], "descriptions": ["high-pressure water motor, for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in.", "These motors are frequently used in mine workings, the water for driving being obtained from the delivery pipe of the main pumping engine, and the motor discharging its exhaust water into the mine sump.", "The cylinder of the engine oscillates on two hollow trunnions, closed at the outer ends, the hollow spaces within each trunnion being divided into two compartments, one of which on each side communicates with either end of the cylinder.", "Two slots cut longitudinally in the trunnion serve for ports for admission and exhaust of the water, one giving admission to each end of the cylinder, and the lower part of each bearing there are three ports, a wide one in the middle communicating with the supply pipe, and a narrower one on each side of this leading to the exhaust pipe.", "The oscillation of the cylinder causes those ports in the trunnions to slide over those in the bearings, so opening up each end of the cylinder to exhaust or pressure alternately, just as in the case of an ordinary slide valve.", "The supply and exhaust pipes are each fitted with an air vessel to prevent shocks in the pipes.", "This motor has a cylinder 2.5 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke, and when making 100 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. gives off 1 brake h.p.", "Larger sizes are made up to those having 9 in. cylinders, which, running at 50 r.p.m. exert 24 brake h.p. under 150 lb. pressure."], "other": ["Inv. 1894-182\u201419, 384"]}

Armstrong, Whitworth & Co., Ltd.", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1910", "1914", "1908"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["type of engine in which a shaft, having an oblique disc or swash-plate fixed to it, is caused to rotate by the successive pressures upon the disc of a number of pistons, working in cylinders arranged in a circle, with their axes parallel with the shaft", "may have a large number of cylinders compactly arranged and gives a very uniform torque", "small example shown has 16 cylinders bored horizontally in a single casting", "pistons are packed with cup leathers and bear against the rounded ends of the piston-rods", "outer ends of the rods are ball-shaped and are held in a circular ring which bears against the swash-plate, ball bearings being interposed to reduce the friction", "ring is controlled by two diametrically opposite pins which slide in horizontal slots attached to the bed-plate of the engine", "end thrust is taken by a row of balls placed between the back of the swash-plate and a fixed disc which is surrounded by an outer casing formed in one with the driving shaft", "valve gear is of the simplified form patented by Mr. F. G. D. Johnston and Sir W. G. Armstrong, Whitworth & Co.", "single rotary valve is used, placed behind the cylinders and having five inlet and five exhaust ports disposed in a circle; the valve seat has 16 cylinder ports symmetrically arranged, and these are connected with the cylinders in a particular order", "arrangement besides reducing the number of ports in the valve, and therefore its size, also requires that the valve shall rotate at only one-fifth of the speed of the main valve. shaft, this reduction being effected by means of epicyclic gearing", "valve opens and closes the cylinder ports at the ends of the stroke, and eight cylinders are working while the remainder are exhausting", "engine may be reversed by interchanging the inlet and exhaust pipes", "cylinders are 0.75 in. diam.", "water pressure is 1,000 lb. per sq. in.", "A full-size sectional drawing is also shown"], "other": ["working", "Received 1914", "Inv. 1914-676", "S.M. 1,135", "Mr. F. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1848"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["shown arranged for clock-winding", "doing lighthouse work", "by tidal energy", "The machine is erected over a tank or well to which the tide has access", "into this hangs a weight and also a float, connected by a chain that passes over a sprocket wheel on the overhead shaft, then round a loose wheel on the framing and back over another sprocket wheel.", "These wheels are connected with the shaft by ratchet and pawl mechanism, which causes both upward and downward movements of the float chain to rotate the shaft, always in one direction.", "The power so obtained will cease for a while during the turn of the tide, and therefore when continuous motion is required, an additional mechanism is added.", "On the end of the intermittently rotated shaft is a sprocket wheel, and on the shaft to be continuously rotated, which is in line with it, is another sprocket wheel; over the two wheels hangs an endless chain, in the loops of which are two weighted sheaves, one of which is much the heavier, the difference being the driving weight.", "When the tidal motion is rapid the excess power is stored by lifting the weight, while, when the tidal movement stops, this weight gives off its stored energy in descending, and so keeps the driving shaft in motion.", "The weighted sheaves are connected by a hanging chain which prevents the inequalities in the effort which would otherwise arise from the varying length of chain on the driving side."], "other": ["Inv. 1858-9"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A tidal motor that harnesses tidal energy to power a mechanism.", "The motor comprises a system of weights, floats, chains, and sprocket wheels that convert the rise and fall of tides into rotary motion."], "other": ["Object Type: Scientific Instrument"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Hero of Alexandria"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1897", "1914", "about A.D. 50"], "places": ["Alexandria"], "descriptions": ["Aeolipile (working)", "Motive Power drawing; drawing", "aeolipile, which consists of a hollow ball mounted on its axis between two pivots, one of which, being hollow, serves as a steam pipe from the cauldron below, supporting the whole. The ball is provided with two bent nozzles, in a plane at right angles to the line joining the pivots. The reaction or unbalanced pressure due to the escape of the jets of high pressure steam tangentially to the ball, causes it to revolve on its axis. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1897"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["French engineer and architect proposed and published in 1615 an application of steam as a means of elevating water. His scheme required a spherical copper boiler with an internal pipe reaching nearly to the bottom, and with a cock for filling it. The boiler was to be placed on a fire until the steam pressure forced the boiling water through the vertical pipe to a height proportionate to this pressure. In an alternate scheme he proposed using the heat of the sun\u2019s rays to increase the pressure of a confined volume of air, and thus force up some of the water upon which it pressed."], "other": ["Prepared in the Museum (drawing preparer)", "Inv. 1897-112, 19,606"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["apparatus \u201cfor raising of water and occasioning motion to all sort of mill works, by the impellent force of fire.\u201d"], "makers": ["Thomas Savery"], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Society"], "dates": ["1699"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The apparatus in its simplest form consisted of a high-pressure boiler supplying steam to a receiver, which was provided with suction and delivery pipes and the corresponding valves. By means of a regulator valve worked by hand, steam from the boiler was admitted into a receiver which, acting through it till the air had been expelled; then the supply of steam was cut off and cold water from a cistern above was turned on to the receiver which, acting as a surface condenser, condensed the steam, so forming a partial vacuum into which the water rose from the suction pipe, the delivery orifice being at the same time sealed by its valve; the entering water further assisted in this condensation. Steam was then again admitted, and by its pressure forced the water in the receiver out through the delivery valve and pipe, the suction pipe in the meantime being closed by its non-return valve."], "other": ["Phil. Trans. XXI. 1699, p. 228.", "Inv. 1897-117", "19,391"]}

Desaguliers, about the year 1740", "it is perfect, but has not been followed absolutely.", "The machine consists of a boiler, 8.75 in. diam., directly above which is a vertical cylinder fitted with a piston, 2.25 in. diam. by 7.75 in. stroke. To the other end of this beam a similar chain is secured, and carries the pump rods which are connected with the buckets of two vertical pumps, 1.25 in. diam., which divide the total lift into stages. Both the steam valve and the injection cock are actuated by pins in the plug rod. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ATMOSPHERIC ENGINE"], "makers": ["Francis Thompson", "Smith & Co.", "Butterley Iron Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Inst. Min. Eng."], "dates": ["1791", "1920", "1772", "1841"], "places": ["Ashover, Derbyshire", "Oakerthorpe Mine in Derbyshire", "Pentrich Colliery near Ripley", "Chesterfield"], "descriptions": ["Plate III, No. 1", "designed and erected", "This atmospheric engine was designed and erected in 1791 by Francis Thompson of Ashover, Derbyshire.", "It was first employed at the Oakerthorpe Mine in Derbyshire until 1841 when it was re-erected at Pentrich Colliery near Ripley, where it worked until 1918; it was thus in commission, except for short intervals, for nearly a century and a quarter.", "It exhibits the characteristic features of Newcomen\u2019s engine, but embodies improvements in detail made as a result of experience by a succession of engineers, amongst them John Smeaton in 1772.", "These improvements consist in mounting the cylinder on a foundation instead of supporting it on beams above the boiler; the use of a mushroom type valve for the inlet steam instead of the sector sliding valve, and additions to the working gear for convenient handling.", "The cylinder was cast by Smith & Co. of Chesterfield.", "This and other parts of the engine from various makers were brought together on the site and there erected by the contracting engineer.", "The great beam was originally made of timber but was replaced at the time of re-erection by the present cast-iron beam with separate arch heads, made by the Butterley Iron Co.", "The beam weighs 14 tons and measures 24 ft. 8 in. between centres of piston and pump chains.", "The cylinder is 54 in. diam. and the piston is 11.5 in. in depth, the rods of which are connected to the beam by forged iron link-chain.", "The piston is packed by rope and canvas kept in place with rings and cast-iron sector plates.", "A cock admits water to the upper surface of the piston to flood the packing and prevent air leakage, while a deep channel around the top of the cylinder drains the excess into the hot well.", "Steam at a pressure of from 2 to 3 lb. was supplied from a haystack boiler through a pipe 10 in. diam., latterly, exhaust steam from a fan engine was used.", "Directly below the steam inlet is placed the eduction pipe, terminating in a non-return valve situated at the bottom of the hot well, the temperature of which was 145\u00b0 to 175\u00b0 F.", "The injection is fed by an L bend under the middle of the cylinder ending in an adjustable carrot valve.", "The snifting valve (so called from the noise it makes when it expels the air that has entered the cylinder with the steam and injection water) takes the form of a lightly-weighted mushroom valve of gun-metal, 2 in. diam., bolted to the eduction pipe.", "Connected to the great beam is a smaller wooden beam operating a lift pump for raising water from the hot well to supply the gravity feed tanks above the boiler.", "The injection water tank contains a small balance lever and circular clack valve which was used to shut off the water when the engine was not working.", "The piston is shown in the position that is reached when the engine stops working, but the weight of the pump rods would, in practice, quickly bring the piston to the top of the stroke.", "To start work, steam is blown through the cylinder till well heated up, the injection cock is opened by hand, and the engine maker the downward, or power stroke, by the pressure of the atmosphere on the piston.", "As the latter nears the bottom of its stroke, a tappet on the plug rod cuts off the injection water, and by raising the detent, which slips under it, prevents the decisive valve opening during the up-stroke.", "At the bottom of the stroke the steam valve is opened and the pressure on both sides of the piston being equalised, the overweight of the pump rods raises the piston.", "On nearing the top of its stroke the tappet on the plug rod closes the steam valve and the injection valve detent is released, thus enabling the engine to repeat the cycle of operations automatically.", "The pump rods, bolted together at the top, were carried down to three separate lift pumps in the shaft, situated 120 ft., 210 ft. and 360 ft. below the surface respectively.", "The pumps are single acting buckets (a spare one is shown) the lowest one being 12.75 in diam., the upper ones each 12.5 in. diam., and the stroke, originally 7 ft. was altered to 6 ft. so that at its normal rate of eight pumping strokes per min. and a pressure on the piston of 7 to 7.5 lb. per sq. in., which was that considered to be the most economical in these engines, the h.p. would be 25; about 250 gallons per min. were raised to a height of 360 ft.", "The engine is shown in its correct surroundings, materials having been brought from Pentrich for the purpose."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-124", "John Smeaton", "Anderson, Trans. Inst. Min. Eng., 1917, LII, 396\u2013445", "cylinder on a foundation instead of supporting it on beams above the boiler", "mushroom type valve for the inlet steam instead of the sector sliding valve", "working gear for convenient handling", "40.5 cm diam. (54 in. diam.)", "29.2 cm (11.5 in.)", "8.4 tonnes (14 tons)", "7.5 m (24 ft. 8 in.)", "2 to 3 lb.", "25.4 cm (10 in.)", "3-4.5 bar", "62-79\u00b0C", "5 cm (2 in.)", "3.25 cm (12.75 in.)", "31.75 cm (12.5 in.)", "6 ft.", "2.1 m (7 ft.)", "8 strokes/min", "0.48-0.52 bar (7-7.5 lb./sq. in.)", "25 h.p.", "950 litres/min (250 gallons/min)", "110 m (360 ft.)", "5.6 kg/cm\u00b2", "1.25 bar"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["complete, and shows an excellent surface condenser and air-pump.", "The condenser is circular, and is traversed by 140 small tubes soldered into a metal tube plate at each end. The cooling water passes through the interior of the tubes.", "A vertical air-pump is attached to the side of the casing, and consists of two tubes united below. The short one is the barrel of the air-pump and is fitted with a solid piston. The longer one is fitted with a delivery valve at the top, and a suction valve where it is connected with the lower end of the condenser.", "The exhaust steam entered the upper portion of the condenser, and the lower outlet opened into the column of the air-pump in such a way that the rising and falling of the water column with the motion of the air-pump piston removed all air from the condensed water. In this way an excellent vacuum would be maintained, and modern engine air-pumps are only found efficient when they accord with the principles here observed by Watt.", "Through the difficulty found in maintaining this form of condenser tight, Watt soon discarded it for the jet form, but now with improved methods of construction the tubular surface condenser is the form most in use, chiefly owing to the supply of pure water that it gives ready for returning into the boiler."], "other": ["Plate II., No. 2.", "Watt Collection", "Inv. 1876-1268", "11,866", "S.M. 801 and 804."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PORTIONS OF BOULTON AND WATT PUMPING ENGINE", "Boulton and Watt pumping engine", "\"Old Bess\" pumping engine"], "makers": ["James Watt", "Matthew Boulton"], "organisations/institutions": ["Branson & Gwyther"], "dates": ["1777", "1861", "1848"], "places": ["Soho, near Birmingham", "England"], "descriptions": ["The parts here preserved belonged to the \u201cOld Bess\u201d pumping engine which was erected in 1777 by James Watt at Matthew Boulton's manufactory, Soho, near Birmingham.", "The engine embodied the separate condenser, the first improvement made by Watt upon Newcomen's engine.", "Watt first knew him was a manufacturer of ornamental metal articles and used water-wheels to drive his machinery.", "In dry weather when the flow diminished six to ten horses had to be brought in to assist; to lessen such expense, this pumping engine was installed to pump water from the tail race back to the head race, as shown by the adjoining model (see No. 66), a practice not unknown even after Watt had made his engine rotative.", "The steam cylinder is 33 in. diam., the stroke is 7 ft. and the pump is 24 in. diam.", "On being dismantled a small furnace beneath the steam cylinder was discovered.", "It is known that in his very early engines Watt used such a furnace to re-evaporate the water which condensed in the steam case and thus reduce steam consumption."], "other": ["Inv. 1861-45", "Newcomen's engine", "adjoining model (see No. 66)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1769", "1773", "1894"], "places": ["Kinneil", "Scotland", "Birmingham", "Hull"], "descriptions": ["working model", "constructed from the data given by the existing portions of the engine, together with those on two early drawings", "shows the general arrangement of the engine erected at Boulton\u2019s manufactory at Soho in 1777", "James Watt\u2019s first steam engine was constructed and tried at Kinneil in Scotland in 1769, and was sent to Birmingham in 1773. At Kinneil the engine, although it had a separate condenser (see No. 62) and embodied other improvements, was hardly a success owing to its defective mechanical construction. When Watt joined Boulton the engine and boiler were conveyed from Scotland by water via Hull to Birmingham, and for two years the engine was being rebuilt and improved, until, with a new bored cast-iron cylinder, 2 ft. stroke, it worked fairly well. It was known as \u201cBeelzebub,\u201d and had an 18 in. cylinder, 5 ft. stroke, and worked an 18\u00b75 in. pump against a 24 ft. head. In 1777 it was injured by fire, and \u201cOld Bess\u201d was constructed immediately afterwards; it was, however, of considerably more power, as the steam cylinder is 33 in. diam. with a 7 ft. stroke, and the pump has a diam. of 24 in. Its duty was to pump water from the tail-race back into the head-race of a water-wheel of 24 ft. diam. and 6 ft. breast, at times when the stream flow was insufficient. This indirect method of obtaining rotatory motion by steam power had previously been employed in London and elsewhere. Long after the introduction of the rotative steam engine, however, this method of driving was still practised for textile machinery, owing to the more regular motion that it was considered was obtainable by the intervention of a water-wheel. The power lost must, however, have been considerable, for if the mechanical efficiency of the water-wheel and its gearing was 50 per cent. and that of the pumps 80 per cent., the combined efficiency could only be 40 per cent., which would be only one-half of the mechanical efficiency of a directly rotative engine, so that twice the amount of coal then necessary would be consumed in doing the required work."], "other": ["Plate II., No. 3", "Scale 1: 12", "Inv. 1894-151, 21, 530, S.M. 229"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1897", "1774"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 28", "Represents the arrangement supplied by Messrs. Boulton and Watt in 1788, but it differs only in detail from the standard Cornish pumping engine subsequently so extensively used.", "The engine valves are of the drop type, connected by racks and segmental arms with levers struck by tappets on the plug or air-pump rod; the top valve admits steam to the cylinder and was known as the \"expansion\" valve, as it was shut off when the piston was at about half-stroke, thereby allowing the remainder of the stroke to be performed by the expansion of the steam previously admitted which performed the work upon the boiler.", "The lower or \"equilibrium\" valve is opened when the piston reaches the bottom of its stroke, thus allowing the steam above the piston to pass to the lower side, so that by the weight of the pump-rods the piston ascends to the upper end of the cylinder.", "The lowest valve controls the passage from the lower end of the cylinder to the condenser, and is open throughout the down-stroke of the piston.", "The well-known high economy of these engines is largely due to their acting somewhat as if compounded, since the upper portion of the piston and cylinder are never exposed to the low temperature of steam discharging into the condenser; the cylinder also has a steam jacket.", "The closed top cylinder here employed was introduced by Watt in 1774.", "The boiler shown is of the \"wagon\" type (see No. 340), and probably worked at about 5 lb. per sq. in. above atmospheric pressure."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-123"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": [], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power drawing"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODEL OF TWIN CYLINDER ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a double cylinder engine in which both cylinders are single-acting but have their piston rods connected by a chain, so that working alternately they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder.", "The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved wheel carrying a crank pin at the back, which would drive a connecting or pump-rod.", "The upper ends of the cylinders are closed but in free communication, and a non-return valve in each piston will permit steam to pass upward into this space.", "Below each cylinder is an air pump and condenser, the air-pump rods being connected by a chain passing over and fixed to a smaller wheel (now missing) on the overhead shaft.", "At the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened alternately with the boiler and the jet-condenser which is in the eduction pipe leading to the air-pump."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1264", "S.M. 802"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Experimental model of twin cylinder engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt collection"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model", "model"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF AN INVERTED CYLINDER PUMPING ENGINE", "Bull engine"], "makers": ["James Watt", "Edward Bull"], "organisations/institutions": ["Newcomen"], "dates": ["1765-6", "1793-5", "1876"], "places": ["Cornwall"], "descriptions": ["arrangement of direct-acting pumping engine", "proposed by Watt in 1765-6 when introducing his separate condenser, but abandoned in favour of the beam construction adopted by Newcomen", "introduced and constructed on a practical scale by Edward Bull", "erected several important pumping plants in Cornwall", "infringing Watt's patents, and in 1793-5 were stopped by legal proceedings", "cylinder is supported over the pumping shaft by beams extending across the engine house, and the main rod passes through the bottom of the cylinder and is directly attached to the pump spears, the weight of which performed the downward stroke of the pump (in the model it is assisted by a leaden weight). Beneath the cylinder is a short rocking beam by which some of the weight of the spears is counterbalanced, and from which the motion for the valve gear and air-pump is obtained. From the sectional model it is seen that the exhaust pipe is provided with a jet and used as a condenser, which is cleared by a vertical air-pump; the jet is, however, intermittent, being controlled by the valve gear so that it is only turned on during the exhaust stroke."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1254a", "1513", "S.M. 831", "S.M. 837"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Inverted cylinder pumping engine"], "makers": ["Richard Trevithick"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1765"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model of an inverted cylinder pumping engine, inspired by James Watt's early proposals from 1765. This design was later developed and popularised by Edward Bull and Richard Trevithick, who manufactured and installed several such engines in Cornwall. The engine features a cylinder mounted above the pump shaft, with the main rod directly connected to the pump spears. The downward stroke of the pump is aided by the weight of the pump spears, with an additional lead weight in the model. A counterbalancing beam beneath the cylinder helps manage the weight of the spears and drives the valve gear and air pump. The sectional view reveals an intermittent jet condenser, activated only during the exhaust stroke and cleared by a vertical air pump."], "other": ["2009-1174"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ORIGINAL INDENTURE"], "makers": ["James Watt", "Matthew Boulton"], "organisations/institutions": ["Samuel D. Liptrap and partners", "Durward Street"], "dates": ["March 1st, 1786", "1908", "1781\u201384"], "places": ["a distillery near Whitechapel Road"], "descriptions": ["indenture of agreement", "for the erection and maintenance by the latter of a double-acting rotative beam engine", "for the payment to the former of an annual premium of 63l. during the unexpired term (i.e., of 14 years) of Watt's patent.", "The engine was to be of 10 h.p., having a cylinder 17 in. diam. by 5 ft. stroke, to be used for grinding malt or other grain and for pumping water, \u201cworts\u201d and \u201cwash.\u201d", "The very important step of adapting the engine to produce rotative motion in order that it might enter the wide field of industrial employment was made by Watt in 1781\u201384.", "Forestalled in the use of the crank, he schemed several equivalent mechanisms (see No. 174\u20138); he made the engine double-acting and invented the parallel motion to take the place of the flexible connection between the piston rod and the beam.", "Boulton and Watt sold their pumping engines on a royalty of one-third of the saving in coal resulting as compared with an atmospheric engine doing the same work, and on the introduction of their rotative engine adopted a \"premium\" similarly based on the saving resulting as compared with the power (e.g., of 10 horses) which was replaced."], "other": ["Messrs. J. S. Smith, Druce & Co.", "Inv. 1908-185"]}

["This is a very early example of the double-acting rotative beam engine with separate condenser and air pump, constructed by James Watt.", "It was erected at Soho Manufactory, near Birmingham, in of timber bound together by straps and bolts.", "The cylinder is 18.75 in. diam. by 4 ft. stroke, and Watt's parallel motion is used to transmit the movement of the piston to the beam.", "The latter is of timber, equal-armed, and actuates by a cast-iron connecting rod and sun and planet gearing (see No. 174), a mortice-toothed flywheel which at Soho drove two pinions 3 ft. diam. from the shafts end of the beam.", "The nozzles to the cylinder were fitted in 1833 to replace the original ones.", "The valves are operated by tappets on a rod which serves also to work the air pump.", "The steam admission for one end of the cylinder and the exhaust valve for the other are released and then acted on by a weight while the corresponding valves are held closed by a detent.", "An early example of Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Rotative Steam Engine", "Rotative Beam Engine", "the 'Lap' engine"], "makers": ["Boulton and Watt", "James Watt", "Matthew Boulton"], "organisations/institutions": ["Soho Manufactory"], "dates": ["1788"], "places": ["Birmingham, borough of Birmingham, West Midlands, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["This is the oldest essentially unaltered rotative engine in the world.", "Built by James Watt in 1788, it incorporates all of his most important steam-engine improvements.", "The engine was used at Matthew Boulton\u2019s Soho Manufactory in Birmingham, where it drove 43 metal polishing (or \u2018lapping\u2019) machines for 70 years."], "other": ["Motive Power beam engine; steam engine; beam engine; steam engine", "1728-1809", "1736-1819"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF DOUBLE CYLINDER ENGINE"], "makers": ["Isaac Mainwaring", "Matthew Murray", "Jabez Hornblower"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1792 (Patent)"], "places": ["Manchester"], "descriptions": ["Two cylinders single acting have their piston rods connected by a chain over a wheel so that, working alternately, they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder.", "Isaac Mainwaring, in 1792, patented a twin-cylinder engine in which the piston rods were racks gearing into a toothed wheel on the axis of the beam.", "This patent was taken over by Matthew Murray and Jabez Hornblower, who developed the invention into the form shown by the model, and actual engines were made in Manchester.", "The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved pulley carrying a crank pin at the back which might drive a pump rod or a connecting rod.", "The upper ends of the cylinder are closed but in free communication, and a non-return valve in each piston will permit steam to pass upwards into this space.", "Below the foot of each cylinder is an air pump and condenser, the air pump rods being similarly connected by a chain (parts missing); at the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened in turn with the boiler and with the jet condenser, which is in the eduction pipe leading to the condenser."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1264"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A DOUBLE-ACTING BEAM ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1876", "about the year 1800"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["improvements upon those in the actual engine, No. 75, erected in 1797", "framing is of timber, supported under the beam gudgeon by a metal column carried on a masonry pedestal", "beam is a casting, and has its terminal pins carried in trunnion hoops which adjust themselves to any inaccuracy in the erection", "valves are of the drop type, two for each end of the cylinder; the stem of the lower valve passes through the tubular stem of the upper one, rendering only one opening into the steam box necessary while simplifying the mechanism", "valves are driven by a quiet tappet gear from a horizontal shaft rocked by an eccentric on the crank-shaft, but the valve gear does not permit of expansive working", "beam is fitted with Watt's parallel motion, and by the looping of the lower tie rod the air-pump rod is directly connected with the parallel point, in the way that has since been generally followed", "condenser is cylindrical and is enclosed in a water tank", "air-pump, the discharge of which is led off by a shoot", "injection water is conveyed to the condenser by a horizontal pipe from outside the tank", "top cover of the air-pump is guided as in No. 78"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1254", "S.M. 862", "20,700"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A BEAM ENGINE (working)", "No. 76"], "makers": ["O. W. Osman, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. Boulton and Watt"], "dates": ["1859", "1895\u201361", "1861-47"], "places": ["Birmingham"], "descriptions": ["Scale about 1:8.", "The general arrangement including the valve gear is similar to No. 76.", "The valves are of the tubular or \u201csocket\u201d type, introduced by William Murdock, rendering only one opening into each valve box necessary.", "The straight line motion of the air-pump rod is obtained from a pantograph extension of the main parallelogram as in No. 76.", "This was discarded for the simpler plan, which subsequently became general, of attaching the rod to the \u201cparallel\u201d point and looping the tie rod to clear it.", "The condenser is contained in a large rectangular tank situated under the cylinder.", "This tank also contains the air-pump which is provided with a cover carrying a stuffing-box through which the pump rod passes.", "The latter, by the friction of the packing, lifts the cover as far as permitted by three guiding stops, and is similarly lowered on the down stroke, an arrangement equivalent to a mechanically-moved delivery valve.", "Inv. 1895\u201361", "Inv. 1861-47, 19,642"], "other": ["scale 1:8", "19,642"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Rotative Beam Engine", "model; steam engine; rotative beam engine", "Motive Power model"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Boulton & Watt"], "dates": ["c. 1805", "after 1800", "1797-1804"], "places": ["Borough of Birmingham", "West Midlands", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["It represents the rotative steam engine as Watt left it upon the expiry of his patents in 1800.", "Cast iron has replaced timber in the main engine components, and the sun & planet gear has been replaced by a more straightforward crank.", "The nozzles (valve boxes that controlled the inlet and exhaust of steam at each end of the cylinder) each contain two concentric socket valves of the type introduced by William Murdock after 1800.", "The eccentric driving the valves was also his improvement.", "steam engine", "rotative beam engine", "Tongue, William"], "other": ["c. 1804", "scale 1:8"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A BEAM ENGINE WITH SUN AND PLANET MOTION"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1869"], "places": ["Southwark"], "descriptions": ["Represents a double-acting rotative engine.", "Framing, the beam, and the connecting rod are of wood.", "Watt\u2019s parallel motion and his sun and planet gear (see No. 174) are fitted.", "To obtain a straight line motion for the air-pump rod and to avoid fouling the rods of the main parallelogram, the latter is extended as a pantograph to give a guided point for attaching the rod.", "Tappets on this rod strike a fork keyed to an internally toothed segment gearing with teeth on the plug of a four-way cock for admission and exhaust of steam to the cylinder.", "An engine embodying this valve gear but with cast-iron, etc., beam, was in use in 1808 at Southwark.", "A circular saw arranged on a bench is driven by a band from the engine.", "Scale about 1: 8."], "other": ["Inv. 1869-64."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A SINGLE-ACTING ROTATIVE ENGINE"], "makers": ["W. W. S. Westwood, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Corbyn's Hall Ironworks", "Soho Foundry"], "dates": ["1894", "1782", "early part of the 19th century", "subsequent to 1800", "1784", "1800"], "places": ["Staffordshire", "the Midlands"], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 8", "method of obtaining rotative motion from an open-topped cylinder provided with Watt's separate condenser", "difficulty of there being only one working stroke per revolution", "connecting rod is so weighted as to store one half of the work done in that stroke and restore it during the idle stroke", "Watt contemplated, in his patent of 1782, using an expedient of this kind for his single-acting engines, but it is difficult to believe that it was ever adopted, because his double-acting engine followed immediately after", "Atmospheric engines, however, had to be so arranged to make them work rotatively (see No. 58)", "large numbers were employed in the Midlands in the early part of the 19th century under the name of whimseys", "For pumping, a similar arrangement is known to have been adopted (see No. 93)", "bears internal evidence of having been made subsequent to 1800", "was for many years at Corbyn's Hall Ironworks, Staffordshire, whither it is said to have been sent from Soho Foundry", "was at one time used for driving a lathe", "The cylinder is 2\u00b76 in. diam. and the stroke 3 in.; the piston rod is guided by Watt's parallel motion (1784), but the air-pump rod is hung from the end of the radius rod, instead of from a parallel point", "The condenser and air-pump stand in the hot well; the former has a cock on the side and a drop valve, by which the injection could be regulated", "The steam and exhaust drop valves are driven by a countershaft from an eccentric, a mechanism introduced for this purpose by Murdock in 1800"], "other": ["Inv. 1894-138", "21,467", "(Lent by)", "model", "Motive Power model"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1897", "1797 (Patent date)"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This arrangement, patented in 1797 by the Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D., was followed in the construction of several engines of the time. Although intended for steam, Cartwright pointed out that the engine might be worked by the vapour of \"ardent spirit or ether.\" A single-acting vertical steam cylinder is employed, having its piston-rod carried down to the bucket of the air-pump, which is placed below in an immersed condenser of the surface type formed by enclosing a cylindrical shell within another of larger diameter. The piston is forced downward by steam pressure until it nearly reaches the bottom of its stroke, when a spring on the crosshead closes the steam valve; the spindle of an exhaust valve in the piston afterwards strikes the cylinder bottom, and so permits the steam to escape into the condenser, thus allowing the piston to pass again to the top of the cylinder under the action of the fly-wheel. The packing of the piston and its rod are stated to have been entirely of metal, and were early examples of metallic packing."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-125", "30,064"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1797"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power drawing"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF CARTWRIGHT'S ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Museum (Maker)"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This model shows Cartwright's mechanism for converting the reciprocating motion of the piston into rotary motion.", "The engine itself presented several exceptional features (see No. 94), but the only other one of these followed in this model is that the valve motion is directly derived from that of the piston by a tappet action.", "The arrangement for guiding the end of the piston-rod, in place of the then general parallel motion, comprised a long crosshead secured to the piston-rod and revolving in opposite directions.", "In this way the oblique thrusts of the two connecting rods were caused to neutralise each other, and the piston-rod had only to resist the direct piston effort, which it was able to do without the assistance of a parallel motion or other form of guide.", "This arrangement of mechanism was abandoned for many years, but it is now successfully employed for driving the two revolving prisms in the rotary form of air-pump know as a \"pressure blower\"; in such cases, however, the engine crosshead is also provided with slide guides, as shown in an attached illustration."], "other": ["Inv. 1902-14."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["model", "Motive Power model"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Edmund Cartwright's steam engine"], "other": ["Science Museum"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF OSCILLATING ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["W. Murdock, Esq.", "William Murdock, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Soho"], "dates": ["1894 (Lent date)", "1785 (Constructed)", "1894"], "places": ["Soho"], "descriptions": ["This is the original model stated to have been constructed in 1785 by William Murdock at Soho.", "The cylinder is 1.5 in. diam., 4 in. stroke, and double-acting.", "It is made of wood, and so was probably tried only with compressed air\u2014a method of driving that was afterwards practically adopted by Murdock for power transmission.", "The framing consists of two \"A\" frames well braced together and supporting the shaft, which is furnished at one end with an over-hanging crank, and at the other with a large fly-wheel.", "The crank pin is directly attached to the piston-rod\u2014the cylinder oscillating on central trunnions.", "The piston is short and long, so that through which the working fluid is introduced, while the other is merely a mechanical support.", "From the inlet passage the driving fluid passes by a channel to a valve chest on the side of the cylinder.", "The valve is a long piston of square section greatly reduced in the centre, which is the steam space.", "The exhaust escapes by the open ends beyond the valve.", "The valve spindle is continued upward, and by a V-shaped link is attached to a stationary point on the same level as the trunnions.", "The oscillation of the cylinder causes a longitudinal motion to the valve which gives a simple distribution of steam, but one which is not quite equal in both strokes.", "An eccentric in the middle of the crankshaft drives a small pump through the intervention of a lever which is so arranged as to double the stroke.", "Although the model worked satisfactorily, it was many years later before the merits of this type of engine were fully realised as the most compact arrangement for driving paddle-wheels, and for many other purposes.", "At the time the model is stated to have been made, Watt was employing the sun and planet gear to avoid using a crank."], "other": ["Lent by W. Murdock, Esq.", "Inv. 1894-133-19,261.", "working"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1881"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines.", "The boiler shell is of cast iron 1 in. thick, 3.6 ft. diam., and 5.5 ft. long; the back end, which is dished, is cast with it, while the front of the shell has a flange to which the wrought iron front of the boiler is secured by bolts.", "To this front the two ends of the return, or horseshoe, flue are riveted; the larger leg of the flue is 18 in. diam. and holds the grate, the return portion being only 10 in. diam.", "The front of the boiler also has a manhole, but the system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed.", "The steam generated passed into a cast-iron steam dome, surmounted by a 2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve, from which it was led by an external pipe to the valve chest of the steam cylinder, which is 9.5 in. diam. by about 36 in. stroke.", "The cylinder is arranged vertically, and is steam jacketed, being almost immersed in the boiler to which it is secured by an upper flange.", "The boiler steam, after passing through a stop valve of the plug type, is admitted alternately to the two ends of the cylinder by a four-way plug valve worked by a tappet motion."], "other": ["Inv. 1881-57-25,244"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF MURRAY\u2019S ENGINE (WORKING).", "No. 100", "fly-wheel shaft"], "makers": ["Matthew Murray"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1902", "1802", "1666"], "places": ["Museum"], "descriptions": ["Shows the mechanism adopted in the self-contained engine, patented in 1802 by Matthew Murray (see No. 100), for converting reciprocating motion of the piston into rotary motion of the shaft.", "It is an application of the fact, originally published in 1666 by De la Hire, that when a circle rolls within another of double its diameter, any point in the circumference of the rolling circle describes a straight line.", "Murray appears to have been the first to construct practically a machine embodying this method of obtaining a straight line, or \u201cparallel\u201d motion", "he, moreover, fully describes a means of taking up the wear on the centre of the rolling wheel by the use of adjustable double cones.", "On the fly-wheel shaft is a crank pin having loose on it a spur wheel of equal radius to the crank path, while on the rim of the spur wheel is secured a crank pin to which the piston-rod is directly attached", "the spur wheel engages with an internally geared rim of double its diameter rigidly secured to the engine framing.", "By these arrangements a guided straight line motion is obtained without the use of links or guides", "while, owing to there being no extension of the piston-rod or anything beyond it, the engine is remarkably compact", "Murray\u2019s mechanism possesses the further advantages of giving a true harmonic motion", "and having all its parts revolving so that they can be directly balanced", "while there is a total absence of oblique thrust.", "For these reasons it is, although now no longer used in steam engines, still extensively adopted for giving reciprocating motion to the tables of flat-bed printing machines as shown by a model in another Section."], "other": ["1902", "Inv. 1902-15", "working"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BEAM ENGINE"], "makers": ["Matthew Murray"], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M. I"], "dates": ["1805", "1907"], "places": ["Leeds"], "descriptions": ["This form of \u201cportable\u201d or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds.", "It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made.", "It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes.", "The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet.", "A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conducting material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water.", "The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank.", "The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel.", "The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam.", "Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided.", "Steam is distributed to the cylinder by the \u201clocomotive\u201d slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802.", "The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke.", "The injection cock to the condenser can be adjusted by a hand lever moving over an index plate."], "other": ["Inv. 1907-23", "portable", "condensing", "self-contained"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF TABLE ENGINES (working)"], "makers": ["Henry Maudslay"], "organisations/institutions": ["Maudslay Collection"], "dates": ["1807"], "places": ["Lambeth Works"], "descriptions": ["The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail.", "Many engines of this kind were made; till the Lambeth Works were closed in 1900, two of them were regularly engaged there in driving some of the machinery.", "The cylinder is carried vertically on a cast-iron table, beneath which are the crankshaft bearings and the condensing arrangements.", "The piston-rod passes through the top cover and terminates in a balancing or articulated crosshead carrying a pair of wheels which roll between guides formed in an independent framing secured to the table and the cylinder.", "From the cross-head there are two connecting rods, which proceed to two independent cranks in the crankshaft below.", "The steam is distributed by a plug valve rocked by a rod connected with a triangular cam on the crankshaft.", "The air, cold water, and feed pumps are worked by an inverted T-bob driven by a roller on the intermediate portion of the crankshaft."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 4 and 1 : 24", "Inv. 1900-23, 25,501, and Inv. 1900-194"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF TABLE ENGINES (working)"], "makers": ["Henry Maudslay"], "organisations/institutions": ["Maudslay Collection"], "dates": ["1807", "1900"], "places": ["Lambeth Works"], "descriptions": ["Scale 1 : 4 and 1 : 24", "The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail.", "Many engines of this kind were made; till the Lambeth Works were closed in 1900, two of them were regularly engaged there in driving some of the machinery.", "The cylinder is carried vertically on a cast-iron table, beneath which are the crankshaft bearings and the condensing arrangements.", "The piston-rod passes through the top cover and terminates in a balancing or articulated crosshead carrying a pair of wheels which roll between guides formed in an independent framing secured to the table and the cylinder.", "From the cross-head there are two connecting rods, which proceed to two independent cranks in the crankshaft below.", "The steam is distributed by a plug valve rocked by a rod connected with a triangular cam on the crankshaft.", "The air, cold water, and feed pumps are worked by an inverted T-bob driven by a roller on the intermediate portion of the crankshaft."], "other": ["Inv. 1900-23", "25,501, and Inv. 1900-194"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Model of Maudslay's 1807 table engine (scale 1:24) with associated components", "Motive Power model table engine; model table engine 1807"], "makers": ["Maudslay, Sons and Field Limited"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Lambeth, London", "London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["made by Maudslay, Sons and Field Limited, Lambeth, London, 1807"], "other": ["Henry Maudslay"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF TABLE ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1892"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a self-contained and compact form of vertical engine in which, moreover, a long connecting rod is used; the arrangement is, however, expensive to make and unsuited for high speeds, so that the inverted cylinder type of engine has practically supplanted it. The cylinder is mounted on a cast-iron table, which is supported by four columns upon a base plate carrying the crankshaft bearings. The piston-rod passes through the top cover of the cylinder, and its crosshead slides in two pairs of guides cast with the cover. The connecting rod is in the form of a loop, or \u201ckite,\u201d embracing a single crank in the shaft. The slide-valve is worked by a similar \u201ckite\u201d rod from an eccentric which also drives the horizontal force pump for feeding the steam boiler. The speed is regulated by a simple centrifugal governor which controls a disc throttle valve in the steam pipe."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 8.", "Inv. 1892-76, S.M. 1219."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["High Pressure table Engine", "working model of High Pressure table Engine"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": [], "other": ["Motive Power model - representation; table engine; model - representation; table engine"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["South Kensington"], "dates": ["1879", "1811"], "places": ["Hayle Foundry, Cornwall", "Trewithen"], "descriptions": ["Plate IV., No. 1", "This early high-pressure engine and boiler were made by Richard Trevithick in 1811 at Hayle Foundry, Cornwall, for Sir Christopher Hawkins, Bart., of Trewithen, and were in constant use for thrashing, chaff-cutting, and similar work, until removed to South Kensington in 1879.", "It is stated that this was the first steam engine that drove a thrashing machine.", "The boiler is of the Cornish type, 7 ft. long by 4.5 ft. diam., with a single internal flue 27 in. diam.; beyond the fire bridge the circular shape is departed from, one side of the flue being flattened so that the section is 28 in. by 21 in.", "The products of combustion from the furnace flue were led by a \u201cwheel draught\u201d through external masonry flues to the chimney, the total heating surface so obtained being probably about 50 sq. ft.", "The shell of the boiler is shaped at the top so as to receive the steam cylinder, which is open-topped and placed in the boiler so as to be steam-jacketed.", "The safety valve is weighted for a maximum pressure of 40 lb. above the atmosphere.", "The cylinder is 9.5 in. diam. by 26 in. stroke, and the long connecting rod, which is attached directly to the piston, passes up to a crank on a fly-wheel shaft above.", "The fly-wheel is 10 ft. diam., with a grooved rim for a driving rope, and has cast on it a balance weight that assists the return stroke of the piston.", "Steam distribution is by a four-way cock which is rocked by a cam on the crankshaft.", "The feed pump is worked by a lever from the piston."], "other": ["Inv. 1879-57", "25,515"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1802"], "places": ["England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power high pressure steam engine", "high pressure steam engine"], "other": ["Hayle foundry"]}
