Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1915", "about 1830\u201340"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine", "for factory purposes", "It was in use till 1905 for driving a set of drying rolls", "The cylinder is 7.25 in. diam. by 14 in. stroke", "The slide valve is of unusual design, being a hollow box, shaped like a flat inverted U, the legs of which slide on a flat seating joining the cylinder ports and forming the front of the valve chest", "Live steam surrounds the valve and passes underneath to the inside edges of the steam ports, while the exhaust takes place through the interior of the valve to a port at the lower end of the valve face which leads to an exit in the base of the cylinder", "A spring on the back of the valve keeps it to its face when steam is shut off", "The valve is actuated by an eccentric with a gab-ended rod", "A butterfly valve throttled by a Watt centrifugal governor controls steam admission to the valve chest", "An interesting feature is the parallel motion, which is a modification of that of Watt; the radius rod is centred at a point above and half way between the end of the beam and its gudgeon, while the link connecting the end of the radius rod and the beam is extended to the parallel point, to which the piston rod is attached", "This form of motion is compact and simple, and does not require the pantagraph of the ordinary Watt motion", "The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century"], "other": ["Inv. 1915-128", "self-contained non-condensing"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM MODEL OF DOUBLE-CYLINDER ENGINE"], "makers": ["Elijah Galloway"], "organisations/institutions": ["Institution of Civil Engineers"], "dates": ["1868", "1839"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This illustrates a type of engine in which dead centres are avoided although only one crank is employed.", "The device was patented in 1839 by Elijah Galloway, but was not practically used until considerably later (see Nos. 124 and 125).", "Two vertical simple cylinders are placed side by side, with the crankshaft between them, and the piston-rods are connected by return links from the ends of the base of a triangular frame, the apex of which embraces the crankpin, while the middle point of the base is constrained to move in a vertical line."], "other": ["Inv. 1868-23"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["William Freemantle", "Oliver Evans"], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Horticultural Gardens", "Royal Albert Hall"], "dates": ["1803", "1804", "1840 till 1870"], "places": ["America"], "descriptions": ["intermediate between the older beam engine and the direct-acting type", "effort of the piston is transmitted to the crank without passing through the beam gudgeon as in the ordinary beam type, so that frictional loss is reduced", "cylinder is vertical, 10 1/4 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke", "piston rod is connected to a beam about four times the length of the stroke", "centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead", "fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine", "Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well"], "other": ["Inv. 1921-533", "steam pressure was 50 lb. by gauge"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1921"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a Grasshopper engine, a type of reciprocating steam engine.", "It features a vertical cylinder and a unique beam arrangement that reduces friction and provides a straight-line motion for the piston rod.", "The engine was used for pumping water."], "other": ["SMG 25594/1"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF GRASSHOPPER OR HALF-BEAM ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1869"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114)", "has been known also as the half-beam engine", "The cylinder is vertical and its piston-rod is connected with a crosshead whence two connecting rods return to a double-throw crankshaft below", "The crosshead is fixed in one end of the beam, the other end being pivoted on two rocking links; the centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles, half the length of the beam, attached to the framing", "A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead", "The air-pump is attached to the \u201cparallel\u201d point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam", "A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam", "Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft", "A Watt governor controls the throttle valve", "The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform"], "other": ["about 1 : 12", "Inv. 1869-63, 19,278"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["A. J. Hill, Esq., C.B.E.", "William Fairbairn & Co., of Manchester"], "organisations/institutions": ["William Fairbairn"], "dates": ["about 1840", "1920", "1922 (till)"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["DRAWING (Scale 1: 8) AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF FAIRBAIRN & CO.'S DOUBLE-COLUMNAR ENGINES.", "Two high-pressure single-cylinder vertical engines of the form introduced by William Fairbairn are here combined to drive one overhead shaft.", "The framing is in the form of a hollow column resting on a box from which the cylinder depends.", "The box is supported by two cast-iron girders which are built into the wall of the engine house, thus doing away with the necessity for heavy foundations and economising space.", "The cylinders are 12.6 in. diam. (bored out from 12 in.) by 30 in. stroke.", "The slide valve is of the loco. pattern actuated by an eccentric; the exhaust is carried away below the floor.", "Speed is controlled by a Watt governor to each cylinder driven by bevel gear from the crankshaft and acting upon a butterfly valve in the steam pipe.", "As fitted, each cylinder could run alone, e.g., when shops were not on full load or when repairs were necessary.", "In 1920 this contingency did arise owing to a breakdown, and for a week the engine worked satisfactorily with one cylinder.", "The stop valve is worked by a handle placed close to the column.", "At 41 r.p.m. and boiler pressure of 125 lb. per sq. in. the estimated h.p. was 145.", "The spur fly-wheel is 10 ft. 2.5 in. diam. at the pitch line, giving 92 r.p.m. on the shop shafting.", "These engines were made in sizes from 6 to 30 h.p., the boiler pressure being about 60 lb. per sq. in."], "other": ["Inv. 1922-293 & 294.", "Scale 1: 8", "(See Fairbairn\u2014Mills and Millwork, Pt. I., 246.)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Petrie & McNaught"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1923", "early part of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as \u201cMcNaughting\u201d and was extensively followed.", "In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines."], "other": ["Inv. 1923-535"]}

Milner"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1857", "1853 (patent)"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["two-stage expansion engine", "cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles", "Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages", "The steam is first admitted into the smaller cylinder and is cut off at half stroke; it is then led to the larger cylinder whose piston is at the commencement of its stroke", "While the piston is at the end of its stroke, this steam will have been doing work while expanding to a volume equal to that of the low- pressure cylinder and half the high pressure", "This method of working causes, however, an exceptional temperature range in the high-pressure cylinder"], "other": ["Scale 1: 4"]}

Fuller, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1893", "1853"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This three-cylinder engine would now be described as a two-stage expansion engine with one high-pressure and two low-pressure cylinders.", "The cranks are equally spaced at 120 deg., this arrangement being adopted with the intention of obtaining uniform turning moment.", "In the model the central cylinder is the high-pressure one; by using two low-pressure cylinders a single cylinder of inconveniently large dimensions is avoided.", "Into the ports are fitted cylindrical plug-valves, by rotating which the distribution of the steam to the cylinders can be varied.", "To assist in following the action, the high-pressure steam ports and spaces are coloured red and the low-pressure black."], "other": ["Mr. Fuller (patent)", "Inv. 1893-173"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DOUBLE-CYLINDER DIAGONAL ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1896"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents an arrangement of engine patented by Mr. Laybourne in 1879.", "There are two diagonal cylinders acting on a single overhanging crankpin; the guides for the crossheads are formed on the front covers of the cylinders.", "The slide-valves are driven by a single pin, projecting from a block that is fixed in a slot formed on a return crank keyed to the crankpin.", "When the block is at one extremity of the slot the valves work as in forward gear, while when at the other extremity they secure backward running.", "The block is moved in its slot for reversing by worm and pinion gear, engaging in a rack fixed in the slot; this gear is adjusted by a small hand-wheel, if held while the engine is running, brings the valves into mid-gear, and then when rotated moves them into the desired position."], "other": ["Inv. 1896-90"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["VERTICAL STEAM ENGINE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1913"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["compact form of direct-acting engine in which a connecting-rod is dispensed with, the piston-rod being directly connected with the crankpin by a block sliding in a transverse slot formed in the crosshead", "arrangement is sometimes known as a \"dog-crank\"", "has been much used for feed pumps", "cylinder is 4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke", "placed vertically on a bedplate which also serves as the bottom cover", "crosshead is very wide, above the cylinder in bearings cast on the top cover", "crosshead is very wide, and is formed of two gunmetal bars bolted together with distance pieces between their ends, the latter also acting as slipper blocks, which slide on two round guide bars rising from the bedplate and tied together at the top", "steel block, made in halves, embraces the crankpin and fits in the crosshead slot, so that as the crank revolves the block slides along the slot through a distance equal to the stroke of the crank", "arrangement allows the engine to be very short, but it introduces large bending stresses in the piston-rod, which is, therefore, made of large diameter", "mechanically the arrangement is equivalent to a connecting-rod of infinite length, and the piston has a simple harmonic motion", "ordinary slide-valve is used, operated by a disc crank on one end of the shaft, and a fly-wheel is mounted on the other end of the shaft"], "other": ["Inv. 1913-304", "S.M. 560", "4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["working", "This type of steam engine is designed for conditions requiring a high speed and great compactness in the mechanism, and is largely used for driving dynamos and fans, also the propellers of the Whitehead torpedo\u2014in this latter case using compressed air.", "The three cylinders are single-acting and arranged at 120 deg. round the common crankpin, have spherical small ends, which work in a cup formed upon which fit pistons fitted with metallic packing, there being no piston-rods.", "The cylinders being single-acting, there is no reversal of stress in the connecting rods, so that slackness in the connecting-rod brasses does not cause a heavy knock, as would be the the case in a double-acting engine\u2014a circumstance which is conducive to quiet working at high speeds.", "The crank chamber is closed and retains a quantity of lubricant\u2014an arrangement which prevents the dust and grit from getting into the working parts, and also economises oil.", "The crank is of the overhanging type, with a counterbalance weight, and the pin drives a small crank-arm connected with the valve gear.", "Steam is distributed to the cylinders by three piston-valves driven by a crankpin, the valve motion for each cylinder being equivalent to that in an ordinary engine.", "The governor, which is beyond the valve gear and enclosed in a removable cover, controls a small throttle-valve of the piston type, and loaded by a spring, which can be adjusted by an external hand wheel that the speed of the engine can be varied while running.", "This example has cylinders 3 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke, and indicates 5 h.p. when running at 600 r.p.m.", "It is shown driven by power with some of the covers removed so as to render the internal construction visible."], "other": ["1888-184", "21,075"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HORIZONTAL STEAM ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Messers. R. Hornsby & Sons"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a high-pressure engine, with a steam-jacketed cylinder supported throughout its length on a cast-iron bed.", "The guides are cast with the bed and bored out, the crankpin is attached to an overhanging crankplate and the outer end of the crankshaft is carried by an independent bearing.", "The engine is fitted with a governor gear that automatically adjusts the degree of expansion to the work being done.", "On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump.", "The others drive the main slide-valve and the \"back cut-off\" or expansion-valve.", "The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor.", "When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor.", "The cylinder is 12.25 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke ; when the engine is supplied with steam at 60 lb. pressure and is making 95 r.p.m., it indicates 50 h.p. ; the same design was followed for engines with cylinders up to 22 in. diam. by 40 in. stroke indicating 185 h.p."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 4", "Inv. 1885-123", "19,274", "19,366", "working"]}

Hornsby and Sons Limited"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Grantham, Lincolnshire, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Model of a horizontal stationary steam engine", "Motive Power models", "stationary steam engines", "horizontal engines"], "other": ["scale 1:4", "1885", "Grantham", "1885"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["high-speed horizontal engine of American design", "The cylinder, which is 5 in. diam. by 7 in. stroke, is overhung", "finished externally by polished metal lagging covering the flanges as well as the usual non-conducting felt", "The crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs", "there are also two fly-wheels", "the crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings", "the crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator", "these various arrangements being resorted to on account of the high speed employed", "The slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves", "it is driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels", "The governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs", "When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant"], "other": ["Inv. 1888-236"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODELS OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE AND DYNAMO (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1884", "1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1 : 4", "This type of engine was patented by Mr. P. W. Willans in 1884 ; with subsequent modifications it was extensively adopted for the direct driving of dynamos.", "The engine is of the single-acting, two-stage expansion type with two high-pressure cylinders and two low-pressure ones, arranged with the high pressures above, and all acting on a two-throw crankshaft with the cranks 180 deg. apart.", "The guide or crosshead for the small end of each connecting rod is in the form of a trunk, working in a closed cylinder that acts as an air cushion ; by this arrangement, combined with single-acting cylinders, the pressures on the brasses of the crankpins and shaft are never reversed, so that slack bearings are permissible without any knock resulting, to which feature the high working speed found practicable is chiefly due.", "The steam distribution to each pair of tandem cylinders is effected by a long piston-valve, extending through a trunk which serves as the piston-rod of the two pistons whilst also acting internally as a valve by its passage through the metallic glands at the cylinder end; as the valve face is travelling with the piston, Mr. Willans in his patent of 1885 overcame the difficulty of steam distribution by forming his eccentric on the crankpin.", "The whole of the crank chamber is completely enclosed, to retain the oil which forms a bath at the lower portion of this space.", "The speed is regulated by a spring-loaded centrifugal governor, fixed on the outer end of the crankshaft and adjustable by hand even while running.", "This governor moves an equilibrium piston-valve which controls the admission of steam, but before reaching it the steam has to pass through a separator which removes priming water and any solid impurities.", "working"], "other": ["Inv. 1901-17", "29,806", "Received."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODEL OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Mr. N. Chandler"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1886-8"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a single-acting, inverted, two-stage expansion engine for directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation (see Pumps Section), or other purposes.", "the two cylinders are arranged tandem fashion, with the high pressure above, so that there is a single piston-rod acting downward upon a crankshaft below, while the steam distribution is performed by two piston-valves similarly arranged and driven by a single eccentric.", "The cylinders are cast on a frame which contains guides for the piston and valve-rods, and the bearings for the crankshaft; it also forms a closed chamber in which the oil is retained and distributed over the bearings by the motion of the revolving parts, access to it being, however, obtainable by side doors.", "A special feature of this engine is the construction of the \"sleeve\" at the lower end of the valve, by which, while permitting the passage of the exhaust steam through itself, the valve can close the exhaust port, thus giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts and assist them on their return stroke.", "The action of the steam in the engine is as follows:\u2014Boiler steam is admitted above the high-pressure piston, which then makes a down stroke; in the next up stroke this steam is allowed to pass to the under side of the high-pressure piston and into a receiver, from which, in the next down stroke, it is admitted to the top side of the low-pressure piston; from this, at about the completion of this down stroke, it is discharged into the exhaust pipe, or condenser, with which the lower side of the piston is in communication, except when the cushioning at the end of the stroke is taking place.", "improved", "single-acting", "inverted", "two-stage expansion engine", "directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation", "two cylinders arranged tandem fashion", "high pressure above", "single piston-rod acting downward", "crankshaft below", "steam distribution performed by two piston-valves", "single eccentric", "cylinders cast on a frame", "guides for piston and valve-rods", "bearings for the crankshaft", "closed chamber for oil retention and distribution", "access by side doors", "construction of the \"sleeve\" at the lower end of the valve", "valve can close the exhaust port", "giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts", "assist them on their return stroke", "Boiler steam admitted above high-pressure piston", "down stroke", "up stroke", "steam passed to under side of high-pressure piston", "into a receiver", "admitted to top side of low-pressure piston", "discharged into exhaust pipe, or condenser", "lower side of piston in communication", "cushioning at the end of the stroke"], "other": ["Received 1902", "Inv. 1902-130"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HORIZONTAL TANDEM COMPOUND ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Adam Gilbert, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1910"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a very common type of compound condensing mill engine having the two cylinders arranged in line and the piston-rods driving a single overhung crank. The cylinders are mounted on one bedplate, and the front cylinder is connected with the main crankshaft bearing by a girder frame in which the bored crosshead guides are formed. The shaft carries a grooved fly-wheel; a crank disc is fixed to its front end and its rear end is supported on a separate pedestal bearing. The high-pressure cylinder is fitted with double-beat inlet-valves actuated by the variable expansion trip gear patented by Dr. W. R. Proell in 1881. In this arrangement, a horizontal lever, oscillated by an eccentric, has suspended at each end a bell-crank lever; the vertical arms of the bell-cranks have notches at their lower ends, which, in their downward motion, catch upon and depress the ends of short pivoted levers which are connected with the valve spindles. The motion of the rocking lever brings the horizontal arm of the bell-cranks periodically into contact with a horizontal plate, the position of which is controlled by the governor; this causes the notches to slip off the valve levers and allows the valves to close sharply under the action of springs and dash-pots mounted above them. If the speed increases the plate will rise and the valves will close earlier in the stroke. The exhaust-valves are of the \u201cCorliss\u201d type (see No. 135). The low-pressure cylinder has Corliss inlet and exhaust-valves, and the inlet valves have a hand adjusted trip gear of the modified \u201cReynolds\u201d type. A wrist plate, loose on the valve spindle, carries a spring catch, which engages with an arm on the valve spindle; the wrist plate is oscillated by an eccentric and, at a certain point of the motion, the catch is disengaged from the valve arm by a fixed roller, so releasing the valve, which closes under the action of a spring and dash-pot. The positions of the releasing rollers are adjusted by hand. One eccentric serves for all the inlet-valves and another for the exhaust-valves. A Porter governor, provided with a dash-pot for damping out sudden and violent fluctuations, is fitted. The steam pipe between the cylinders forms a receiver, and both cylinders and pipes are lagged with wood. The cylinders are 12 in. and 21 in. diam. by 30 in. stroke; when the engine is supplied with steam at 100 lb. pressure, and is making 110 r.p.m., it develops 136 effective h.p., with economy, or a maximum of 186 indicated h.p. The fly-wheel is 10 ft. diam. and is grooved for five ropes of 1.75 in. diam. The engine is fitted with a jet condenser placed below the floor level, the air and feed pumps being placed beside it and driven by an \"L\" lever from the tail rod of the low-pressure cylinder."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12", "Inv. 1910-31", "S.M. 250", "S.M. 251", "working"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF SEMI-PORTABLE OVERTYPE ENGINE (working)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations.", "The boiler is of the locomotive type, the chief feature of which is the staying of the fire-box (not visible in the model).", "Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given.", "The top and sides of the fire-box are each one steel plate, planed, drilled in position and riveted hydraulically.", "The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank.", "The cylinder is bolted to steel flanged seatings riveted to the boiler and is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate.", "The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation.", "If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted.", "The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve.", "Mechanical lubrication is adopted.", "A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines (see Power Transmission Section) are made."], "other": ["Scale 1: 8", "Inv. 1920-63", "S.M. 1,226", "engine develops 30\u201345 h.p. at 120 r.p.m."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["WATT'S SEMI-ROTARY ENGINE", "semi-rotary engine"], "makers": ["Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Heathfield"], "dates": ["1782", "1897"], "places": ["Heathfield"], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 16", "Prepared in the Museum", "This is copied from Watt's patent specification", "in the Watt Garret at Heathfield, however, there is an unfinished model of this engine, which was commenced in 1765 or 1766", "The engine has a short horizontal cylinder with a radial piston which can swing through an arc of 240 deg.", "The lower sector of the cylinder is fitted with a stationary abutment block through which steam is admitted to either side of the piston alternately.", "Below the cylinders are valve boxes for the distribution of the steam, while beneath these is a jet condenser, and two air pumps which are driven by racks from a pinion on the vibrating shaft.", "A large spur wheel on this shaft has two racks gearing with it, and these move the rods of the two pit pumps that the engine was designed to work; by this latter arrangement the pump rods mutually counterbalance."], "other": ["Inv. 1897-122, 21,053"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["James Watt's Rotary and Semi-Rotary Engines Drawing of James Watt's Rotary and Semi-Rotary Engines"], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": ["1782"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power drawing"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1897"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is copied from the 1782 patent specification of James Watt, but there is no evidence that he ever constructed such an engine.", "The drawing shows a piston in the form of a closely-fitting radial arm projecting from an axial shaft in a cylinder.", "An abutment, arranged as a flap, is hinged, near a recess in the side of the cylinder, and swings while remaining in contact with the piston.", "Steam is admitted to the chamber on one side of the flap, and so causes an unbalanced pressure upon the radial arm.", "The arrangement has been re-invented several times, and has been worked out in a practical form (see No. 142)."], "other": ["(Scale 1: 16.)", "Prepared in the Museum.", "Inv. 1897-122, 21,053."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Rotary and Semi-Rotary Engines"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power drawing"], "other": ["drawing"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["W. Routledge, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1869"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a model of a simple form of rotary engine made and patented in 1818 by Joshua Routledge, whose name is well known in connection with the engineers' slide rule.", "The piston revolves on a shaft passing through the centre of the cylinder casing.", "The flap or valve hinged to the casing, with its free end resting upon the piston, acts like the bottom of an ordinary engine cylinder.", "The steam inlet port is on one side of the hinge, and the exhaust port on the other.", "The admission of steam is controlled by a slide valve, actuated by an eccentric on the flywheel shaft, so that the engine could work expansively, and the steam pressure resisting the lifting of the flap would also be greatly reduced, so diminishing the knock.", "The only point which, however, would always be a serious cause of trouble.", "The exhaust steam passes down to a jet condenser, provided with a supply of water from a containing tank, from which the injection is admitted through a regulating valve.", "The air pump which draws the air and water from the condenser and discharges them through a pipe passing out at the end of the tank, is a rotary machine constructed like the engine, driven by spur gearing from the flywheel shaft.", "Some efforts to prevent leakage have been made by forming grooves in the side of the revolving piston and filling them with soft packing."], "other": ["Inv. 1869-62", "19,376"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Bolton le Moors, Lancashire"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model"], "other": ["Mounted on cast iron tank"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A ROTARY ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Rev. Patrick Bell, LL.D."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1868"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This engine shows one of the early attempts to obtain rotary motion from the pressure of steam without the intervention of a crank and connecting-rod", "almost the same arrangement was proposed in 1838 by Lord Armstrong as a water motor, and an example subsequently constructed gave off 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent", "A metal disc is secured to a horizontal axis carried in bearings, and the lower half of the disc is enclosed by a chamber of circular section having its axis a semi-circle", "One end of this chamber is closed and provided with a pipe through which steam enters, the exhaust taking place through the open end", "The disc is provided with three holes, each fitted with a circular plate turning on an axis radial to the disc, and these plates when set at right angles to the disc become pistons in the lower enclosing chamber", "Toothed gearing is arranged to rotate these pistons into the plane of the disc on leaving the cylinder and back again immediately after entering, locking levers retaining them in position during the intervals", "The steam pressure upon these pistons forces the disc round, but the engine is non-expansive, and although some provision for packing has been made, the leakage must have been considerable and the wear and tear excessive"], "other": ["Inv. 1868-24", "19,371"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Bell's Rotary Engine", "Patrick Bell's Rotary steam engine"], "makers": ["Patrick Bell"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Scotland", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Motive Power model"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF A DISC ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["R. B. Prosser, Esq.", "Messrs. E. and J. Dakeyne", "Messrs. W. Taylor and H. Davies", "Messrs. Ransomes and Sims", "Messrs. G. and J. Rennie"], "organisations/institutions": ["Marine Engineering Collection"], "dates": ["1830", "1841", "1893"], "places": ["Liverpool"], "descriptions": ["The disc engine was patented by Messrs. E. and J. Dakeyne in 1830, and subsequently improved by Messrs. W. Taylor and H. Davies, besides others.", "In 1841 Messrs. Ransomes and Sims showed at Liverpool a Dakeyne rotary engine of 5 h.p., the first portable engine on wheels.", "It drove a thrashing machine and was rendered self-propelling by pitch chains from the crankshaft to the travelling axle.", "A similar engine was applied with some success by Messrs. G. and J. Rennie to drive a screw propeller (see Marine Engineering Collection); more recently the arrangement has been extensively used as a water meter.", "The chamber, which acts as a cylinder, is enclosed laterally by a spherical zone and endwise by a pair of cones whose apexes come together.", "The piston is a circular disc fitting the interior of the zone round its edge, and having at its centre a ball which forms the joint on which it gyrates.", "From the ball, and perpendicular to the disc, projects a rod whose further end is socketed in a crank arm attached to the shaft to be driven. There is a fixed radial partition in the cylinder, and a corresponding slot in the disc permits of the requisite motion. The disc and partition divide the chamber into four spaces, two of which are expanding while the other two are contracting; steam is admitted into the former and discharged from the latter by ports formed through the spherical wall of the partition, and the disc itself, by its motion over them, performs the function of a valve. The engine may be reversed by interchanging the inlet and exhaust passages."], "other": ["Inv. 1893-172", "21,068"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["John Hick, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1895", "1887"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A cylindrical drum revolves within a fixed cylindrical casing of considerably larger diameter.", "The drum is placed eccentrically within the casing so that the circumference of the revolving drum is in contact with the inside of the casing at one place.", "At one side of this line of contact is the port or passage for the admission of steam, and at the other side of it is the exhaust port.", "The circumference of the drum is divided longitudinally by two slots, fitted with cylindrical packings, through which two flaps or blades extend radially to the circumference of the casing.", "The inner ends of the blades are free to turn on a stud fixed centrally with the casing, and the exposed surface of these blades between the drum and the casing form pistons upon which the steam acts, and so causes them to revolve and carry round the drum."], "other": ["Inv. 1887-76", "21,048", "Inv. 1895-149", "Maudsley Collection, 1900"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF ROTARY ENGINE"], "makers": ["John Trotter"], "organisations/institutions": ["Maudslay Collection"], "dates": ["1805/1852 (Patents)", "1805"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["These wooden models represent the rotary engine patented by Joseph Maudsley in 1852; the same thing had, however, been patented by John Trotter in 1805.", "The engine consists essentially of a rotating cylindrical chamber, within which rotates a smaller cylindrical chamber placed eccentrically so as to touch the first.", "The inner chamber has a slot at one point, through which projects a radial partition fixed to the outer chamber; the crescent-shaped space between the two chambers is thus divided into two parts, one of which is expanding while the other is contracting, as the chambers revolve.", "Steam being admitted through a port in the outer chamber causes an unbalanced pressure upon the partition, the opposite side of which is connected with the exhaust by a port in the inner chamber, and so drives the chambers round.", "One model has the two chambers surrounded by a concentric casing to which the steam is admitted, the exhaust being through the axis.", "The other model is double and has three concentric rings with radial partitions between them, forming two chambers in which two eccentric rings rotate; no steam ports are shown on this model."], "other": ["Inv. 1900-22"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Two models in wood of Maudslay's rotary engine"], "makers": ["Maudslay, Sons and Field Limited"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["c1852"], "places": ["London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Two models in wood of Joseph Maudslay's rotary engine", "Motive Power model"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TOWER\u2019S ROTARY ENGINE WITH WORKING MODEL", "working model"], "makers": ["Messrs. Heenan and Froude"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1889", "1894", "1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A complete 6 in. engine, together with a wooden model, are shown, which illustrate the mode of action of the engine patented by Mr. Beauchamp Tower in 1879, and now known as the \u201cspherical\u201d engine because the working chamber is a complete sphere.", "The mechanism is equivalent to a universal joint connecting two shafts inclined together at an angle of 135 deg.", "The cross-piece of the joint is filled in so as to form a circular piston, and the jaws or bows of the joint are filled in solid to the shape of a quarter of a sphere.", "The whole joint is enclosed in a spherical chamber, and it will be seen that the disc alternately approaches and recedes from the spherical segments to which it is attached, as the shafts rotate.", "Throughout each revolution there are two cavities simultaneously opening, and two closing\u2014all four varying at the mean rate, so that if steam is admitted into the enlarging cavities, and be permitted to exhaust from those that are closing, continuous rotation of the shafts is obtained.", "The rotation of the segments upon the surface of the sphere is utilised to distribute the steam\u2014ports in the spherical surface being uncovered at the correct intervals by the moving segments.", "The chambers obtained in this engine are each equal to a quarter of the volume of the sphere, and in one revolution the total volume passed is equal to that of the sphere.", "As the only reciprocation is that due to the swing of the disc, the engine is suited for high speeds, and, for the power given off, is very compact."], "other": ["Inv. 1889-76", "Inv. 1894-275", "21,060"]}

Fielding, depends upon the oscillating motion which the cross of a universal joint has relative to the containing jaws when the system is rotated.", "Two shafts are set at an angle of 165 deg. to each other and connected by a Hooke\u2019s joint; one serves as a pivot, the power being taken from the other.", "Four curved pistons are arranged on the cross-piece, two pointing towards one shaft and two towards the other, and on each shaft or jaw are formed two curved steam cylinders in which the curved pistons work.", "The steam enters and leaves the base of each cylinder through ports in the shaft, which forms a cylindrical valve working in the bearing as a seating.", "On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine, and the valve arrangement is such that while each piston is receding from its cylinder the steam pressure is driving it, and during the in-stroke of each, its cylinder is in communica- tion with the exhaust.", "There are thus four single-acting cylinders making each a double stroke for one revolution of the driving-shaft.", "The engine has no dead centres", "has been run at 1,000 r.p.m."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-183", "21,061", "Lent by Messrs. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["RIGG\u2019S REVOLVING ENGINE (working)"], "makers": ["Mr. A. Rigg"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1892", "1885"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This machine, patented in 1885 by Mr. A. Rigg, will be found to resemble in its movements an oscillating cylinder engine held by its crankshaft, and performing its cycle by the revolution of the framing round the crankshaft and the cylinder round the crankpin.", "The varying chamber of a reciprocating engine is thus obtained, while the inertia stresses due to the reciprocating parts are almost eliminated.", "The engine has three single-acting cylinders, the long plunger pistons of which act outwardly upon three crankpins, projecting from the face of an overhanging fly-wheel.", "The closed end of each cylinder is formed into an eye, and fits upon a stud or trunnion fixed to the engine-bed.", "This stud is not on the same centre-line as the fly-wheel shaft, so that in a complete revolution each piston makes a double stroke, of a length equal to twice this eccentricity.", "The driving stud acts on a sliding block so that the eccentricity can be varied and the stroke of the engine is rendered adjustable.", "The engine is reversed by sliding the stud into line with the fly-wheel shaft and continuing the sliding so as to give the eccentricity on the opposite side.", "The passage of the working fluid to and from the cylinders takes place through the faces of the eyes at the cylinder ends, which are provided with ports.", "The fluid enters and leaves the engine by the block carrying the stationary stud, the face of the block forming a surface on which the nearest cylinder end revolves, and acting as a disc slide-valve for the three cylinders.", "An adjacent sectional drawing shows clearly the details of this arrangement.", "The engine can be worked by steam, air, or water, but the full advantage resulting from the variable stroke is only obtained when working with water, owing to the cylinder clearance increasing as the stroke is reduced.", "The ordinary speed of these engines is from 100 to 500 r.p.m. with water pressure of 750 lb. per sq. in.", "When steam or compressed air is used, as many as 2,000 r.p.m. have been obtained."], "other": ["Motive Power model", "working", "Inv. 1892-74", "19,372"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ROTARY ENGINE (working)", "rotary steam engine"], "makers": ["Mr. J. F. Cooley"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901", "1903", "1907", "1911"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Its construction depends upon the fact that if two elements rotate in the same direction, about fixed centres, with a speed ratio of 3 : 2, then three points on the slower element, equidistant from its centre, will describe, relative to the faster element, one and the same two-lobed peritrochoidal curve known as a nephroid.", "If a piston of this form is made to revolve at the correct speed, in a suitably shaped revolving chamber, having the three describing points on it in contact with the piston, then the chamber will be divided into three expanding and contracting spaces which can be used as working cylinders.", "In the engine shown, the piston is mounted on a horizontal shaft and placed eccentrically inside a closed cylinder having a trefoil-shaped interior section with packing strips placed at the describing points.", "These strips, which have swivelling heads with two lines of contact, are the only parts in contact with the curved surface of the piston; they are held in contact by springs and have sufficient radial motion to render extreme accuracy of the piston form unnecessary.", "There are also other packing strips fitted in the cylinder ends and bearing against the flat ends of the piston.", "Pinions with 24 teeth are fitted to the shaft on each side of the piston, and these gear with internally toothed rings with 36 teeth fitted into holes in the cylinder end covers through which the shaft passes.", "Both cylinder and piston shaft run in roller bearings mounted in the end covers of an outer casing that surrounds the cylinder, and a ball thrust bearing is fitted to the tail end of the shaft.", "The cylinder has three longitudinal ports cut through it leading to the interior working spaces, and the casing, in which the inlet and exhaust passages are formed, fits closely round it.", "These passages are separated by pairs of adjustable packing strips, fitted in slots in the casing and bearing against the cylinder, and an intermediate strip provides for a period of expansion, admitting, cutting-off and exhausting the steam as the ports pass the packing strips.", "The cylinder ends are made steam tight in the casing by cast-iron rings rotating with it and fitting between two non-rotating gunmetal rings, the outer one of which is adjusted by set-screws passing through the casing cover and pressing on a cast-iron backing ring.", "The longitudinal packings are pressed inward by springs and adjusted by external nuts.", "The bearings have short steel rollers of large diameter which are prevented from winding by closely-fitting side plates; the rollers run on hardened steel rings.", "Such engines could be made to reverse by providing the casing with two sets of inlet and exhaust ports, and suitable valves for bringing either set into use."], "other": ["Received 1911.", "Inv. 1911-14.", "steam inlet of 1\u00b719 in. diam.", "piston 6 in. long", "designed to develop 20 to 30 h.p."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PARSONS STEAM TURBINE AND HIGH SPEED DYNAMO"], "makers": ["The Hon. Sir Charles A. Parsons, K.C.B., F.R.S."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is the original steam turbine, made in 1884.", "It worked for several years driving the dynamo which gave off 5 electrical h.p.", "The motor consists of a series of parallel-flow turbines on the same shaft, the first being the supply for the second, and so on.", "By this arrangement the efficient action of a steam turbine is greatly reduced.", "To allow for the increased volume of the steam as its pressure falls in passing through the machines, the proportions of the turbines alter as the final one is approached, the passages being enlarged and the pitch of the blades increased.", "A set of guide blades, with its corresponding rotating ring, forming one element of a later turbine, is shown separately beside the machine.", "End thrust is obviated by employing two equal series of turbines on the same spindle on each side of the central steam inlet, the exhaust taking place from each end equally.", "By this arrangement also, glands are avoided as the slight leakage through the bearings under the exhaust pressure is easily collected and occasions no loss.", "To prevent vibration the bearings throughout are not quite rigidly fixed to the main castings, but are permitted a slight movement between clamping washers, the alternate washers fitting the casting and clearing the outside of the bearing, and vice versa.", "The lubrication of the bearings is effected by a current of oil continually circulated by a small screw pump formed on the main shaft.", "In its course the oil passes through the hollow shaft of the dynamo so that it shall assist in cooling the armature and commutator.", "The governing is performed by a cylindrical throttle-valve actuated by a leather diaphragm, on one side of which the air pressure is reduced by a kind of fan attached to the main shaft.", "The exhausting action of the fan is partially neutralised by an iron arm turning on a vertical axis, by the attraction of the field magnet, drawn round, against the action of a spring, into a position that causes its extremity nearly to close the entrance to the air-pipe.", "By this arrangement the opening of the throttle-valve is regulated by the centrifugal action of the fan and by the intensity of the magnetic field, the control being partly mechanical and partly electrical.", "The dynamo has a drum armature, but, owing to the high speed employed, only a few convolutions are required, which, being of large section, give a very low internal resistance.", "The commutator is built up of short gunmetal segments insulated with asbestos and dove-tailed into steel rings.", "The machine is shunt wound."], "other": ["Inv. 1890-59", "S.M. 277"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DE LAVAL'S STEAM TURBINE"], "makers": ["Dr. C. Gustav P. de Laval"], "organisations/institutions": ["New York central station"], "dates": ["1889", "1896", "1896-84", "19,249"], "places": ["New York"], "descriptions": ["remarkable steam engine", "discovery by him, in 1889, of the fact that the velocity of the particles of an escaping jet of steam is increased by discharging through an expanding orifice", "conversion of the energy of the steam into momentum being so complete that, when applied to a form of Pelton wheel or impulse turbine (see No. 15), a high efficiency is obtained", "Without the expanding orifice, a simple steam jet turbine is one of the earliest forms of steam engine (see No. 35), and very uneconomical, but by the use of many such turbines in series an efficient engine is also obtained (see No. 151)", "shown in section", "revolving wheel is built up of separate vanes that are clamped by side discs in a way that resists the severe centrifugal stress resulting from the immense velocity required, while at the same time permitting of well-finished and correctly shaped vanes being employed", "steam is directed, at an angle of 19 deg. with the plane of the wheel upon one side of it, through the expanding jet orifice, and after gliding round the concave faces of the vanes leaves the opposite face of the wheel with scarcely any dynamic energy remaining in it", "wheel is enclosed in a casing that communicates either here or with a condenser", "necessary that the velocity of the vanes should be nearly half that of the fluid of the impelling jet (attaining 2,000 ft. per sec.)", "special arrangements are necessary to render it possible", "wheel is fixed to the middle of a long, flexible shaft, one end of which is secured within a shaft carried in bearings, while the other end is carried in a long bearing having a spherical mounting; in this way the wheel is allowed to determine its own axis of rotation in somewhat the same way as does a spinning top", "speed of the shaft is so high, however, that it is unsuited to any ordinary machinery, and is accordingly reduced in one step by helical gearing in the ratio of 10 : 1, the countershaft then running at a speed suited for the direct driving of small dynamos; for slower machinery the reduction can be further carried out by belting"], "other": ["Received 1896", "Invented/Developed 1889", "Inv. 1896-84"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Made in the Museum"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1909"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["diagrammatic model illustrating the principle and arrangement of a steam turbine of the single-stage impulse type", "consists of a single wheel mounted on a shaft, having symmetrically shaped blades round its periphery with an entrance angle of 30 deg.", "turbine is driven by steam issuing from two nozzles, placed tangentially at opposite ends of a diameter, and making an angle of 20 deg. with the plane of the wheel.", "In the model the nozzles are cylindrical, as the exhaust pressure is much greater than one-half of the initial pressure, but in an actual machine using steam at ordinary pressure, a diverging nozzle is necessary in order to utilise efficiently the energy of the steam (see No. 152)."], "other": ["Inv. 1909-481"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a working model illustrating the principle and arrangement of the compound reaction turbine of the Parsons type (see Nos. 151 and 155). It consists of a revolving drum upon which are mounted two rings of curved blades; two rings of similar blades are fixed to the casing and alternate with them, and the steam passes from the inlet end between the fixed and moving sets of blades alternately, while expanding. This arrangement of turbines in series reduces the steam and blade velocities, approximately inversely as the square of the number of rings of moving blades. In the model the casing is made of glass so that the blades may be seen."], "other": ["Inv. 1909-35"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Curtis Steam Turbine", "dynamo"], "makers": ["C. G. Curtis", "General Electric Co., U.S.A."], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1896", "1904"], "places": ["U.S.A."], "descriptions": ["This type of steam turbine was patented by Mr. C. G. Curtis in 1896 and subsequently developed.", "The model represents a turbine for driving a dynamo of 500 k.w. output, made by the General Electric Co., U.S.A., in 1904.", "The turbine is of the impulse type, in which the steam is wholly expanded in diverging nozzles and then has its kinetic energy absorbed by the blades of revolving wheels.", "In order, however, to reduce the peripheral speed of the wheels to a practical value, two methods are simultaneously employed; firstly, the steam is expanded in two stages by two sets of nozzles, and secondly, each wheel has three sets of blades with intermediate fixed guide blades which redirect the steam, after passing through one set, on to the succeeding sets.", "This combined method gives a large reduction in the peripheral speed with a small number of wheels and blades.", "The turbine has a vertical shaft with bearings at the top and bottom, the whole revolving load being carried by a water-jacketed, adjustable footstep bearing which is supplied with oil under pressure.", "The turbine casing consists of three parts, one above the other, a diaphragm being placed between the two upper parts dividing the interior into two chambers in each of which the wheel revolves.", "The lower casing forms a pedestal containing one of the triple wheel-exhaust outlet.", "The shaft is fitted with stuffing- boxes where it passes through the casings and diaphragm.", "The first-stage nozzles and guide blades are fitted in the roof of the top chamber, and the number is twelve, and is supported by a removable door which is adjustable.", "The second-stage diaphragm and are forty the guide blades occupy the circumference and are fixed to the walls of the second casing, in number to allow for the increased volume of steam.", "The second-stage regulation is effected by a nozzle governor which closes or opens some of the first-stage nozzles; the second-stage nozzles are regulated by a large ring-valve acting similarly, but operated by hand.", "The wheels are each built up of three steel discs, bolted together, and the blades are cut around the rim by special shaping machines; the passages thus formed are of constant width, but the depth, and also the blade angles, increase in accord-ance with the decreasing velocity of the steam.", "The guide blades are cut in the same way, in segments, and bolted to the casings.", "The dynamo is placed vertically above the turbine and directly coupled to it.", "The turbine is designed for a steam pressure of 150 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 1,800 rev. per min. and develops 670 electrical h.p.", "It uses about 12 lb. of saturated steam per h.p. hour, at full load, but with high superheat as low as 10 lb.", "Machines of this type have been built to develop more than twenty times the above power."], "other": ["working", "Motive Power model", "Scale 1: 6", "Inv. 1907-15, S.M. 5."]}

Parsons & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 12", "represents a design for a large turbo-alternator for an economical output of 10,000 k.w., with a steam consumption of 13 lb. per k.w. hour, but capable of being overloaded to 20,000 k.w.", "The turbine is of the ordinary Parsons type (see No. 151)", "the low-pressure end bearing is fixed to the alternator bedplate, while the high-pressure end is mounted on a separate one, upon which it can slide.", "The steam valves are mounted on the front of the lower half of the casing, so that the upper half may be removed without disturbing them.", "Oil is supplied to the bearings by a pump and returned to the oil-tank, which is placed under the turbine.", "The overload is provided for by a valve that admits high-pressure steam to an intermediate point along the turbine.", "The alternator is of the stationary armature type, and is entirely enclosed by a casing, through which a cooling current of air is forced.", "The exciting dynamo is mounted on the end of the bed."], "other": ["1909", "15816", "S.M. 276"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["sectional drawing of 500 k.w. combined steam turbine", "compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type", "ordinary Parsons reaction type blading"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1912", "about 1902", "1902-1908"], "places": ["the Continent"], "descriptions": ["This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type.", "This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature.", "The turbine has a solid forged steel rotor carrying 30 rows of reaction blading, while at the high-pressure end a large disc, which carries two rows of impulse blades, is bolted on.", "The nozzles are attached to a cast steel steam chest bolted to the main casing.", "The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum.", "The shaft runs in brass bearings surrounded by sleeves fitted in cylindrical cast-iron housings, which are themselves mounted in the main bearing casings.", "A thrust and adjusting block is placed at the end of the shaft and is adjusted by sliding the bearing cap."], "other": ["Scale: 1:4", "Inv. 1912-14"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Prints from \"Engineering,\" October 17th, 1913.", "These prints show a very large steam turbine, built by Messrs. C. A. Parsons and Co. for the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago in 1913.", "The turbine is made up of two separate casings, each with its own shaft and rotor, the shafts being in line and rigidly coupled together.", "The high-pressure turbine, which is designed for rather less than half the load, has a solid forged rotor steel drum with three diameters, and has 64 rows of moving blades varying in length from 2.75 in. to 6.5 in.", "Balance drums are provided at the high-pressure end, and the bladed portion is nearly 12 ft. long and 65 in. maximum diam.", "Loads exceeding 20,000 k.w. are provided for by a by-pass-valve, which admits steam directly to the twentieth row of blades.", "The steam passes from the high-pressure casing through two pipes, 30 in. diam., to a central chamber surrounding the low-pressure turbine, which is double ended.", "The low-pressure rotor is a cylinder, 14.5 ft. long, mounted on a central spider, and two expansion diaphragms on each side of the casing; it has 24 rows of moving blades 2.75 in. to 19 in. long.", "The condenser, which has a cooling surface of 39,600 sq. ft., is suspended below the low-pressure casing, but a large proportion of the weight is borne by spring supports beneath it.", "Very complete governing gear is fitted, comprising a relay-operated main-valve, an emergency stop-valve, and an automatic overload bypass-valve.", "The turbine shaft is connected with the alternator shaft by a flexible claw coupling.", "The turbine runs at 750 rev. per min., and uses steam at a pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., superheated 200\u00b0 F., and a vacuum of 29 in.", "The guaranteed steam consumption at 20,000 k.w. was 11.25 lb. per k.w. hour, which is equivalent to 8.1 lb. per shaft h.p. hour.", "The overall dimensions of the complete machine are 76 ft. long, 18 ft. wide, and 30 ft. high, but 20 ft. of the latter is below the floor level."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-284", "25,000 K.W.", "k.w.", "k.w. hour"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EXPERIMENTAL BEAMS"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["These models were probably made by Watt when designing beams for his steam engines, as there is evidence that at first the engine beams gave trouble through their insufficient strength and rigidity.", "The smaller beams have parallel top and bottom booms, with diagonal timber struts inclined at 60 deg.; in one case the tie bolts are inclined, and run axially through the timber struts, while in the other vertical iron tie bolts are used.", "In the latter case the model has been loaded to destruction.", "The two larger beams consist each of a lower timber beam with a built-up truss above, the chief difference between them being that in one all the members are in duplicate.", "They have gudgeons and hooks or staples attached by which their strengths could be experimentally determined.", "From their trussing it is evident that these beams were designed for single-acting engines."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1246", "Watt Collection"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SUN AND PLANET GEARING. MODEL OF SUN AND PLANET GEARING"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1871"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Watt was working on the application of the crank and connecting-rod to an engine beam as a means for converting its reciprocating into circular motion when he was forestalled by the patent taken out in 1780 by James Pickard. who, it has been stated, obtained his information through one of Watt\u2019s workmen; Watt, instead of contesting the patent, decided to adopt other mechanism. This and the four succeeding models show some of these mechanisms which he patented in 1781; of these, however, only the sun and planet gear came into use. It is an epicyclic gear consisting of a \"sun\" wheel keyed on the end of the fly-wheel shaft and a \"planet\" wheel bolted to the connecting-rod end and held in gear with the sun wheel by a link loose on their centres, as in the model, or by a pin in the centre of the planet wheel moving in an annular slot. When both wheels are of the same diameter the fly-wheel makes twice the number of revolutions that it would if actuated by a crank and connecting-rod, the extra revolution being due to the fact that the planet wheel, although going round in a circle, does not revolve on its own axis. In some of Watt\u2019s engines the diameter of the planet wheel was less than that of the sun wheel, and in this way shaft speeds were obtained only about 50 per cent. greater than would have been the case with a simple crank."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1258, 17,872 & 19,272"]}

Holt, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1878", "1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This arrangement of valve, patented by Mr. Holt in 1878, combines in one fitting the drainage and relief safety valves for both ends of an engine cylinder.", "Pipes from the two ends enter the casing shown, and the discharged water from the cylinder is carried off by a central pipe.", "In the casing is a valve for each end of the cylinder, and each of these valves consists of a central disc or drain valve, and also of a double-seated annular valve outside, which is the relief valve; these annular valves are kept on their seats by springs.", "The action is such that, when steam is in one end of the cylinder, its pressure opens the drain valve of the other end or exhaust side, while, at any time, the central or relief portion of the valve will open should the pressure, through priming, exceed the limit determined by the springs."], "other": ["Inv. 1879-7"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PISTON ROD PACKING"], "makers": ["United States Metallic Packing Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. W. E. Plummer", "W. M. Kermode"], "dates": ["1902", "1893", "1875"], "places": ["United States"], "descriptions": ["This packing was patented in 1893 by Messrs. W. E. Plummer and W. M. Kermode, and is a development of a form invented by Mr. E. Monroe in 1875.", "Its features are that it permits of free lateral and angular motion of the rod due to vibration, it is self-adjusting under wear, and its contact round the rod is chiefly derived from the steam pressure.", "In the arrangement shown by the sectional specimen the packing is of the duplex type, consisting of two separate sets of packing, the inner series partially resisting the steam pressure and the outer one completing the work.", "The inner packing consists of three babbitt metal rings contained in a conical cup fitted with a gland which is forced home by springs assisted by the steam pressure.", "The front of the cup is free to slide on the plane face of a washer, the other face of which beds in a spherical recess on another washer, while the gland end is free to slide on the plane face of another washer which is forced home by a number of helical springs, but the chief closing pressure upon the gland is that exerted by the steam.", "With the exception of the soft metal rings the whole of these parts are bored much larger than the piston rod diameter.", "The outer packing is similarly held endwise between flat and spherical faces kept in contact by springs assisted by the steam pressure, and so arranged as to give freedom for lateral and angular movement of the rod and its packing.", "The packing itself is, however, quite different, consisting of two rings each made up of gunmetal blocks and two blocks of babbitt metal, all forced inward by radial springs.", "The soft metal sectors break joint and also press upon the rod, while the gunmetal ones are quite clear of the rod; the reduced steam, moreover, which has passed the inner packing exerts a radial pressure upon these blocks which keeps them in closer contact with each other, and also presses the soft metal blocks upon the rod.", "Each babbitt metal block embraces one-third of the circumference of the rod, and as the four blocks break joint the complete circumference is thus fully covered.", "It is claimed that, owing to the closing of the packing being automatically performed by the steam pressure, the arrangement works for many years without attention, and that wear is diminished owing to the pressure being relieved during the exhaust strokes.", "Mr. E. Monroe", "babbitt metal rings", "conical cup", "gland", "springs", "steam pressure", "washer", "spherical recess", "helical springs", "gunmetal blocks", "radial springs", "soft metal sectors", "exhaust strokes"], "other": ["Inv. 1902-149"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["These are examples of the S.E.A. piston rod packing rings patented by Mr. A. R. Trist from 1903 to 1907. They are designed for use with steam or water, and are kept tight by the internal pressure for their steam-tightness, the piston rod moves through them with a minimum of friction. The rings are made of a composite laminated material consisting of alternate layers of textile fabric and rubber, vulcanised together and coated with graphite. They are formed with a thick heel and a tapering lip, which is bent inwards and downwards. The rings are placed one on the other in the stuffing-box with the lip turned in the direction of the pressure, their ends being butted closely together ; header rings of solid packing are placed at the top and bottom, the bottom header ring having an open joint to permit the fluid to pass to the rings. The wide heel of one ring rests on the curved top of the next lower ring, and the inner edge of the heel is made of harder material to prevent it from spreading and filling the arch of the ring, it being essential that the lip of the ring should be free. The gland is screwed up only sufficiently hard to hold the rings tightly together. Experiments have shown that the friction of these rings, when perfectly steamtight, is only about 40 per cent. of that of plain rings. The packings are made in a range of sizes for rods from 0.875 in. to 8 in. diam., and in several widths for each diameter. They are also made with a basis of asbestos, cotton or flax.", "for steam or water", "minimum of friction", "composite laminated material", "alternate layers of textile fabric and rubber", "vulcanised together", "coated with graphite", "thick heel and a tapering lip", "lip bent inwards and downwards", "header rings of solid packing", "bottom header ring having an open joint", "wide heel rests on the curved top of the next lower ring", "inner edge of the heel made of harder material", "lip of the ring should be free", "gland screwed up only sufficiently hard", "friction is only about 40 per cent. of that of plain rings", "made in a range of sizes for rods from 0.875 in. to 8 in. diam.", "several widths for each diameter", "made with a basis of asbestos, cotton or flax"], "other": ["Inv. 1914-193 & 194", "for a rod 2.5 in. diam.", "width of 0.75 in."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SECTIONAL MODELS OF STEAM ENGINE SLIDE VALVES (working)"], "makers": ["Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1902"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This series of eight models shows various modifications that have been employed in this type of valve since its original introduction at the end of the 18th century, chiefly in models of an oscillating engine and a steam carriage (see No. 96 and Land Transport Section).", "As a sliding valve may continue its movement after it has closed any particular passage which it controls, it may be so arranged as to open or close other passages, simultaneously or otherwise, and thus combine the duties of several valves.", "Owing to this feature a single slide valve replaced the four beat valves which were originally necessary in the early double-acting steam engines, and this simplicity, combined with quietness in working, has since led to the general adoption of the slide valve in nearly all classes of steam engines.", "long D", "short D", "common or locomotive", "piston", "double-ported", "Trick\u2019s", "Church\u2019s", "Hackworth\u2019s"], "other": ["Inv. 1902-155 to 162, 26,441 to 26,447 & 27,647"]}

Dawes"], "organisations/institutions": ["Marine Engineering Section"], "dates": ["1897", "1869"], "places": ["S.S. \u201cLopez\u201d"], "descriptions": ["This is a section of a slide valve fitted with the form of relief frame patented by Mr. W. Dawes in 1869. The frame slides upon a planed surface on the inner side of the steam chest cover, and fits around the top of the slide valve. The connection between the frame and the valve is made by a plate of steel or bronze, about 0.05 in. thick, so arranged as to leave a considerable amount of elasticity while securing a steamtight joint between the valve and its frame. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["CYLINDER WITH DROP PISTON VALVES"], "makers": ["Messrs. John & Wm. McNaught"], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1908"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["arrangement of steam engine valves, for reducing cylinder clearance to a minimum", "four separate piston valves arranged at right angles to the axis of the cylinder and working in perforated liners fitted across the steam and exhaust passages, which are cast along the top and bottom of the cylinder", "When the valves are moved outward they uncover the perforations and allow the steam to enter or leave the cylinder", "The piston, which is made longer than usual, is allowed to approach as nearly as possible to the cylinder covers, and the valves have conical inner ends which project between the cylinder wall and the cylinder covers", "Holes are drilled through the valves to balance the steam pressure on their ends", "The inlet valves are fitted with dash-pots and are arranged to be operated by a trip gear; the exhaust valves may be worked by any ordinary gear"], "other": ["Scale 1: 4", "Inv. 1914-753"]}

Hick, Hargreaves & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1863", "1883", "1888", "1848"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["fitted with a modification, patented by Mr. W. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Thomas Silver, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1864"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This represents the form of slide valve and operating gear patented by Mr. Silver in 1864. The valve is elongated and has portions of its ends cut away so that the port area for steam admission is restricted, while the whole area is available for exhaust. Motion is given to the valve by a disc oscillated by an eccentric, the point of attachment of the valve rod being adjustable so that variable expansion and reversing are obtainable. Adjustment is effected by attaching the valve rod to the middle point of a link which slides upon two pins fixed in the face of the disc; and a rack is formed on the back of the link and this gears with a pinion which is rotated by a worm and worm wheel."], "other": ["Inv. 1869-88"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model of a slide valve and its operating gear. The design, patented by Thomas Silver in 1864, features an elongated valve with cut-away ends to restrict steam admission ports while allowing full exhaust. The valve is operated by an eccentric-driven disc, with an adjustable attachment point for the valve rod enabling variable expansion and reversing. This adjustment is achieved by connecting the valve rod to the midpoint of a sliding link that moves on pins fixed to the disc. A rack on the link meshes with a pinion, which is rotated by a worm and worm wheel."], "other": ["Donated by Thomas Silver, 1869"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MOTION DIAGRAM OF HOLT'S REVERSING GEAR"], "makers": ["H. P. Holt, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1879", "1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This auxiliary steam reversing gear was patented by Mr. Holt in 1876.", "The reversing piston has its motion controlled by a three-ported slide valve connected with the reversing lever, but also receiving motion from this piston.", "The ports of this valve are always open to the cylinder, but the passage of steam is prevented by a back cut-off valve of the ordinary type, without any lap.", "For each position of the control valve, which is moved by a hand lever, there is a corresponding neutral position for the three-ported valve, and therefore of the piston, and reversing lever, so that any motion of the small valve is followed by a corresponding movement of the reversing piston until steam is again cut off from both ends of the cylinder."], "other": ["Inv. 1879-73"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Holt's patent 1876 Auxiliary Steam Reversing Gear"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Diagrammatic model in wood"], "other": ["on board Motive Power model - representation", "model - representation"]}

Eng."], "dates": ["1868", "1879\u201380"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["combined reversing and variable expansion valve gear", "patented in 1879\u201380 by Mr. Joy", "had been at work upon the problem since 1868", "model is one of several early ones constructed by the inventor", "shows the application to a horizontal engine", "No eccentrics are used as the motion of the valve is derived from the oval path described by a point in the engine connecting rod", "A valuable feature of the gear is that it brings the valve chest readily into a position at right angles to that usually occupied", "The action of the gear will be readily understood by a reference to the model adjoining (see No. 214)"], "other": ["(Scale about 1:8.)", "(See Proc.
