Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["AMSLER PLANIMETER"], "makers": ["Elliott Bros"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1909", "1884"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["ordinary planimeter of the proportional type, arranged so that the mean heights of indicator diagrams can be directly read", "Two steel points are fitted to the instrument, one fixed at the back of the main bar, near the tracing point, and the other to the sliding piece that carries the hinge and the recording mechanism.", "The distance between the points is equal to the length of the tracing arm.", "The points are set so that the distance between them is equal to the length of the diagram to be measured, and carried round the area in the usual manner.", "The difference in the readings of the recording mechanism, the small divisions on the roller being units, will give the average height of the diagram in fortieths of an inch.", "A brake is fitted to the roller to prevent it from moving when measuring, for averaging, the sum of a number of similar diagrams"], "other": ["Motive Power planimeter; planimeter", "addition due to Mr. Druitt Halpin"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["C. L. Stokoe, Esq., A.M.I.Mech.E."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1921", "1919-1920"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["to warn an attendant of any stoppage or reduction of the flow of liquids or gases passing through a pipe under his charge", "The valve consists in its simplest form of a flap or disc within a conical-shaped casting screwed to the pipe to be controlled.", "The valve spindle has fixed upon it an external weight (or a spring), which is balanced by the normal pressure of the liquid within the pipe.", "On any failure of the pressure the valve turns automatically and moves a lever, which brings into operation electrical or mechanical alarm gear.", "The spindle of the valve is provided with anti-friction glands of special design to allow of rotation without leakage.", "It also resets itself when normal running is attained.", "it is not the static pressure of the water, but its momentum, which keeps the valve open.", "two types of these valves, one for an open-ended pipe, which is the most usual arrangement, and the other for a closed circulation system under pressure, as represented by the example here shown.", "the alarm gear is of several kinds; in this case it is a whistle, which is the device suitable for steam-driven pumps or for air-compressors.", "The connection to the whistle is from the pump steam chest or from the compressor intercooler and thus, while automatic, only functions when the plant is actually working.", "The general arrangement for an air-compressor is shown by a diagram.", "In other cases such as a gas engine having forced circulation of cooling water, the Monitor valve may close an electrical circuit so as to ring a bell, or to actuate a plunger, e.g., to cut the magneto out of circuit.", "Other applications are obvious."], "other": ["Size C", "for a pipe 2 in. diam."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1921"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A safety device designed to alert operators to flow interruptions in liquid or gas pipelines.", "The valve operates by balancing the flow's momentum against a weighted or spring-loaded spindle. Pressure loss causes the valve to rotate, triggering an alarm.", "Features a specially designed anti-friction gland to prevent leakage during rotation and automatically resets when normal flow is restored."], "other": ["Inv. 1921-716"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HAYSTACK BOILER."], "makers": ["Coalbrookdale Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1907", "18th century", "late in the 19th century", "middle of that century", "about 1760", "1748", "about 1790", "1776", "1725"], "places": ["Staffordshire district"], "descriptions": ["This type of boiler, which together with its setting was only an adaptation of existing practice with brewers\u2019 pans and spirit stills, was used throughout the 18th century for supplying steam to atmospheric engines; under the name of the \u201cballoon\u201d boiler it survived in the Staffordshire district till late in the 19th century. The period represented by the model is about the middle of that century. At first it was the practice to place the boiler vertically under the engine cylinder, but about 1760, as the power of engines was increasing, the demand for more steam was met by an increase in the number of the boilers, placed in contiguous settings, rather than in their size. The boiler was under-fired and set in masonry or brickwork, so that the hot gases made a complete circuit of the sides on their way to the chimney in a way known as a \u201cwheel draught.\u201d As the pressure used was practically only that of the atmosphere, the question of construction was subsidiary to that of heating surface; accordingly we find that the flange boiler, which was the type used with the earliest Newcomen engines, had the side flue formed by a horizontal flange uniting vertical sides to a base plate. Later a slight improvement was made by adopting conical or concave sides, hence the name \u201chaystack.\u201d The bottom was at one time recessed so as to form a spiral flue, as patented in 1748 by Thomas Stephens and Moses Hadley, but generally it was flat or concave. Internal stays were but rarely used, and instances of boilers up to 15 ft. diam. without them are recorded. The numerous explosions that had been traced to these defects in shape and construction and the low ratio of heating surface to cubic contents possible, led to the disuse of this type of boiler. The material of which the boiler was made was at first copper, often with lead for the top; the corners appear to have been made by flanging the plates. On account of their durability and less cost, wrought-iron plates produced by hammering seem to have been substituted as early as 1725. Cast iron was also used; even in 1776 Smeaton preferred this material for his boilers. It was not till about 1790 that plates and other sections produced by rolling became generally available. The feed water was introduced through a valve controlled by hand into a cistern on a vertical stand-pipe by which a column of water of sufficient height to balance the pressure within was obtained. The water level was indicated by the position of a lever connected with a float inside. The blow-off pipe was usually stopped simply by a wooden plug.", "Made in the Museum from particulars supplied by the Coalbrookdale Co.", "adaptation of existing practice with brewers\u2019 pans and Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901", "1780-90", "1850", "1901"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This type of stationary boiler succeeded the haystack form (see No. 339), and was a considerable improvement in that it possessed greater heating surface and grate area, while being easier of construction.", "It was introduced by James Watt about 1780-90, and remained in general use till about 1850, when the gradual increase that had taken place in boiler pressures led to its abandonment through the inherent weakness of its shape.", "The boiler usually had a semi-cylindrical top with concave bottom and sides, and was set over the furnace, from which the gases, after passing along the bottom of the boiler, returned along one side flue, and then passed back again by the other side flue, following the course known as a \"wheel draught.\"", "At a later period a nearly square central flue through the boiler was introduced, and the gases from the furnace, after passing under the bottom, returned through this flue, dividing at the front, so that one-half of the quantity passed along each of the side flues, thus originating what is known as the \"split draught.\"", "The feed water was introduced by a vertical stand-pipe, or \"feed-head,\" of sufficient height to prevent water being blown out of it by the steam pressure.", "In this pipe was a float connected with a damper in the main flue, so that if the pressure fell, the rate of combustion was automatically increased; the feed water was supplied to the head from a cistern provided with a valve controlled by a float within the boiler.", "The boiler represented was of 20 nominal h.p.", "The pressure would be 5 lb. per sq. in."], "other": ["No. 339", "20 nominal h.p.", "13.8 ft. long", "6.8 ft. high", "5.33 ft. wide at the water line", "heating surface of 200 sq. ft.", "grate area of 29 sq. ft.", "ordinarily contained 300 cub. ft. of water", "steam space of 115 cub. ft.", "Inv. 1901-20, 25.523"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF HORIZONTAL BOILER ON YIELDING SUPPORTS"], "makers": ["Jeremiah Head"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1870", "1876"], "places": ["iron works"], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 16.", "By this method of supporting a long boiler, patented by Mr. Head in 1870, the ends may rise and fall by expansion without altering the position of the points of support, thus reducing the stresses that frequently cause seam-rips.", "The boiler represented is of the long egg-ended type set in an ordinary brick setting, such as is still used in iron works.", "Pieces of T iron are riveted to the boiler and attached by suspension rods to weighted levers, with their fulcra carried on cast-iron bridges, two intermediate bridges, however, carrying suspension rods fixed by nuts.", "The steam connections are fitted with double bends or U pipes.", "By a hand wheel on the model the boiler may be curved so as to show the action of these supports."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1457", "Lent by"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Model of a horizontal boiler on yielding supports"], "makers": ["Jeremiah Head"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model demonstrating Jeremiah Head's patent (1870) for yielding supports for horizontal boilers. This arrangement allows the boiler ends to move freely with thermal expansion, preventing stress-induced seam failures.", "The model depicts a typical long egg-ended boiler in a brick setting."], "other": ["SMG-G_1876-1457"]}

Coleman and Morton"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1876", "1879"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["experimental model", "consisting of two horizontal shells fixed vertically above each other and connected by seven large necks", "By a long internal tube in each alternate neck, communication is made between the bottom of the upper shell and the lower portion of the lower one.", "When in action, the water heated in the lower vessel rises through the necks, while the cooler water circulates downward through the internal tubes. The steam generated forms in the upper portion of the top chamber, and then passes into a small separating vessel fixed at the top.", "Glass ends have been fitted by which the circulation of the water can be observed.", "The boiler is mounted in a metal setting provided with two side doors, through which the heating surfaces can be cleaned.", "Between the two shells two horizontal plates are fitted, the lower one leaving a space at one end of the boiler and the upper one leaving a space at the opposite end, thus forming flues through which the gases from the furnace below pass backward and forward and backward again before reaching the chimney."], "other": ["Scale 1: 16", "Inv. 1879-13"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1874"], "places": ["Vienna Exhibition of 1873"], "descriptions": ["a pair of Lancashire boilers", "each 7 ft. diam. and 24 ft. long", "with two flues 33 in. diam. reduced to 28 in. at the further end", "The whole of the fittings and arrangements of such boilers are clearly shown", "including the automatic low-water alarm", "double dead-weighted safety-valve", "internal distributing pipe for the feed-water", "perforated collecting pipe for taking the steam from the highest part of the boiler", "The furnace is formed in short lengths of welded tube with the ends flanged out by rolling", "this construction, known as Adamson's flanged seam, greatly strengthens the flue against collapse, and permits of joining the lengths without exposing the rivet heads and thick portion of the joint to the flame", "Eight cross tubes, for increasing the heating surface and circulation of both the water and the gases, are welded into the flue beyond the fire", "The drawing also shows the method of setting and the brickwork flues employed", "The weight of the boiler is carried on two fire-brick ledges, and the flues throughout have a fire-brick lining", "The gases after traversing the two furnace flues, pass downward and along towards the front by a wide flue and at the front the current splits and returns along the two side flues in two streams, which unite again at the base of the chimney"], "other": ["Scale 1 : 24", "Inv. 1874-17"]}

Galloways, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Galloways, Ltd."], "dates": ["1894 (mentioned twice, once as date of manufacture, once as acquisition year)"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1: 12.", "Plate VII, No. 2.", "This represents in section a Lancashire boiler of the \u201c Galloway \u201d type.", "Two furnaces 2\u00b78 ft. diam. unite in one flattened tube 4\u00b76 ft. wide and 2\u00b775 ft. high, forming a combustion chamber which is the feature of the Galloway boiler.", "To give the necessary resistance to the collapsing pressure, thirty-three Galloway water tubes are introduced, the shape of which the flanges are perpendicular to the length.", "To deflect the gases amongst the tubes, four water pockets are inserted in the sides of the shell.", "The furnace flues are welded longitudinally and united transversely by the Adamson flanged joint (see No. 346).", "The shell is in rings, each of a single plate, lap-jointed and double riveted, and the ends are each of a single plate.", "The front end is secured to the shell by a welded angle ring and gussets, and the back end by flanging it over and by the use of gusset stays.", "A 4-in. dead-weight safety-valve is fitted, and also a combined high-steam and low-water safety-valve.", "The actual boiler is 28 ft. long by 7 ft. diam., and is capable of evaporating 6,000 lb. of water per hour, giving 300 h.p. with a good engine."], "other": ["Inv. 1894-137", "19,240"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1918"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Represents generally a Lancashire boiler fitted with corrugated flues (see No. 373) and Galloway tubes.", "The shell is 7 ft. diam. and 27\u00b725 ft. long, while the flues are 33 in. diam. at the front end and 25\u00b75 in. diam. at the back.", "The fitting consists of a dead-weight safety valve, a main stop valve and a combined steam pressure and low water safety valve.", "Two water gauges, a pressure gauge and a feed water valve are mounted on the front plate.", "The upper part of the shell is made removable, so as to show the internal construction."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12.", "Inv. 1918-197."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This shows a type of boiler patented by Mr. W. H. Casmey in 1906. It differs from the Lancashire boiler in that the flues incline upward, and increase in diameter from front to back. This construction has the effect of gradually reducing the quantity of water surrounding the flues and increasing the heating surface as the temperature of the furnace gases falls, thus giving a more uniform generation of steam throughout. It is claimed that a Yorkshire boiler may be considerably smaller than a Lancashire boiler of equal power.", "The boiler shell is 24 ft. long and 9 ft. 4 in. diam., and has two flues, which are 41\u00b725 in. diam. at the furnace end and 45\u00b72 in. at the back end. The axes of the flues rise 5 in. from front to back.", "The shell is formed of four rings, each a single plate, joined by double-riveted lap joints. The longitudinal joints are treble-riveted butt joints with double straps. Each flue is built up of 10 short lengths of welded tube united by Adamson flanged joints. The boiler ends are single plates, the front one being joined to the shell by an angle ring, while the rear one is flanged round the edge. Each end is stiffened and tied to the shell by seven gusset plates. Details of the joints and seats for the various fittings are shown.", "The boiler has a heating surface of 925 sq. ft. and a grate area of 42 sq. ft. It will evaporate from 15,000 to 18,000 lb. of water per hour, from and at 212 deg. F., at the rate of 10 lb. of water per lb. of coal. The working steam pressure is 160 lb. per sq. in."], "other": ["Scale 1: 12.", "Prepared in the Museum", "1920", "Inv. 1920-481.", "Motive Power", "technical drawings"]}

Cochran & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1881", "1878"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["design originated from an idea of Mr. Edward Crompton for embodying some features of the horizontal multitubular boiler in a vertical boiler", "firebox is of hemispherical form, so as to avoid flat surfaces which have to be stayed", "burning gases escape through a circular opening to a combustion chamber above", "gases pass through a number of short horizontal tubes into the smokebox on the opposite side, from which they escape into the chimney", "short tubes are much more efficient than their limited length and surface would suggest", "boiler is built of mild steel, and the model shows fully the details of the method of construction adopted", "surfaces in contact with the water are coloured dark blue, and those with the hot gases red"], "other": ["Scale 1:2", "Inv. 1881-43, 19,273"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Cochran & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1881"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The Cochran vertical boiler was designed by Edward Crompton, who, with J. T. Cochran, patented the invention in 1878. The design aimed to incorporate features of the horizontal multitubular boiler into a vertical format. The boiler features a hemispherical firebox to avoid the need for stays, leading to a combustion chamber. Burning gases then pass through short horizontal tubes into a smokebox and chimney. The boiler is constructed from mild steel, and the model illustrates the construction details. A fire-brick lining is used in the combustion chamber to reduce heat radiation, and hinged doors are fitted to the smokebox for easy cleaning of the tubes. The model differentiates between water and hot gas surfaces by colour coding: dark blue for water and red for hot gases.", "The patent for this boiler design was granted in 1878.", "The model is made of mild steel.", "The firebox is hemispherical in shape.", "The model uses colour coding to distinguish between surfaces in contact with water (dark blue) and hot gases (red)."], "other": ["Accession number: 1881-43, 19,273"]}

Richardsons, Westgarth and Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1878\u201397", "1901"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["construction of vertical boiler embodies several arrangements patented by Mr. J. Furneaux", "The shell is cylindrical with a closed segmental top", "the firebox is a truncated cone surmounted by a vertical cylindrical combustion chamber having a dished top", "The cone is crossed by a large inclined water-tube", "from one side of the combustion chamber 130 fire tubes, arranged in vertical rows, extend radially to the shell", "The ends of some of the tubes are contracted by ferrules to ensure equal distribution of the gases, which pass through them to an external smokebox carrying the funnel and provided with sliding doors to facilitate tube cleaning", "Three small ports in the shell, admit warm air directly into the combustion chamber to prevent the discharge of smoke or unconsumed gases", "The shell of the boiler is extended downward to form the sides of the ash pan; the grate, however, is not shown", "The combustion chamber or flue tube is divided halfway up by a horizontal diaphragm of fire-clay, so notched that it can be passed up from below and then rest on ferrules projecting from some of the tubes", "In this way the hot gases are caused to rise through the lower rows of tubes to the smokebox on the outside, whence they return through the upper rows to the flue and pass out by a central chimney", "There are ninety-six of these tubes arranged in vertical rows, but the whole circumference is not occupied, two spaces being left for scaling purposes, and the smokebox is formed in two portions"], "other": ["Inv. 1903-52 & 53"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF GURNEY'S WATER TUBE BOILER."], "makers": ["Sir Goldsworthy Gurney"], "organisations/institutions": ["Navy Office"], "dates": ["1825", "1827", "1923"], "places": ["Regent\u2019s Basin"], "descriptions": ["For the purposes of his steam carriage Sir Goldsworthy Gurney patented, in 1825, a water-tube boiler which he modified subsequently, as shown, for stationary use.", "The boiler was made of wrought-iron pipes bent to a C shape, the ends being screwed and held by nuts in cast-iron horizontal headers joined by downcomers.", "The headers were joined by bends to a vertical steam \u201c separator \u201d of wrought iron strengthened by hoops.", "This was provided with gauge cocks and a lever safety valve.", "The lower legs of the pipes formed the grate and brick baffles were inserted to make the course of the gases circuitous.", "Lightness, ease of repair and rapidity in getting up steam were claimed as the advantages but difficulties with materials were met with, e.g., pipes at that time were lapwelded and in lengths of not more than 6 ft.", "Probably the circulation was defective ; anyhow the boiler did not survive.", "The heating surface of this boiler was about 60 sq. ft.", "the grate area 5\u00b76 sq. ft.", "the content of water was 160 lb."], "other": ["Scale 1: 6", "Received 1923", "Patented 1825", "Constructed 1826", "Inv. 1923-517", "The time required to get up steam from the coal was 14 min.", "The evaporation was 6\u00b77 lb. water per lb. of good Newcastle coal at 60 lb. pressure."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["J. Harrison, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1862", "1859"], "places": ["Philadelphia"], "descriptions": ["Scale I: 15; details I: 2.", "This steam generator was patented in 1859 by Mr. Joseph Harrison of Philadelphia.", "It consists of a large number of communicating globular iron chambers, cast in sets of four ; the ends of each set are machined so that tight joints can be made when several sets are held together by internal tie-rods.", "In this way the cells are connected into slabs, while by suitable castings and tie-rods a number of these slabs are similarly united to form a complete boiler of the requisite heating surface.", "The slabs are arranged with a slope of 25 deg. in a brickwork chamber, the furnace being at the lower end and the steam pipe at the top, while suitable bridges distribute the gases between the nests of cells.", "About one-third of the cell capacity is used as steam space, and in it a certain degree of drying or superheating is effected.", "Exceptional portability and adaptability were claimed for the arrangement, as well as great safety, owing to the smallness of the individual elements of which the generator is built up.", "The boiler has since been somewhat modified, and as now constructed is given a slope of 40 deg. with the horizontal.", "On trial it was found that one of these generators, when tested to 875 lb. steam pressure, leaked considerably at the joints, but that it became tight again upon the pressure dropping to 450 lb.", "In some forms of sectional tubulous boilers the use of internal tie-rods has given trouble owing to the expansion of the external tube being greater than that of the rod."], "other": ["Lent by J. Harrison, Esq., 1862.", "Inv. 1862-115."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODELS OF STIRLING BOILER", "one in section"], "makers": ["Mr. A. Stirling"], "organisations/institutions": ["Stirling Boiler Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1903", "1889"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This type of water-tube boiler was patented in 1889 by Mr. A. Stirling", "The boiler consists of a number of groups of steeply-inclined tubes, expanded at their upper ends into three cylindrical steam and water chambers, and at their lower ends into two cylindrical mud drums, in which the water, being comparatively quiet, deposits its sediment.", "The feed water is admitted to the upper chamber farthest removed from the fire, and this chamber contains the automatic float for regulating the water level.", "The tubes leading thence to the mud drum serve as downcomers for the water passing to other sections of the boiler and, in heating the feed water, act somewhat like those of an economiser.", "The sides, roof, and floor of the boiler are of brickwork, but the weight of the boiler is carried, and the walls supported, by a steel framing.", "There is a brick arch above the furnace, which assists in directing the flames towards the tubes, and between the groups of tubes are baffles, formed of fireclay slabs, arranged so as to cause the hot gases to traverse the whole of the tube surface before reaching the chimney through the damper door at the back.", "Through the side wall there are protected openings which give access for the scraping tools used in cleaning the exterior of the tubes.", "The steam generated is withdrawn from a steam dome fixed upon the central chamber, into which the steam from the wing chambers is led by curved horizontal pipes, an arrangement which, it is stated, conduces to dryness in the steam.", "The complete boiler represented is of the middle size constructed, and has 56 sq. ft. of grate area, 2,900 sq. ft. of heating surface, and would supply about 12,000 lb. of steam per hour at a pressure of 160 lb., giving about 600 h.p. with a suitable engine.", "A print of a boiler in longitudinal section is shown."], "other": ["(Scale 1:12.)", "Inv. 1903-46 & 47, 29,905.", "Inv. 1903-112."]}

Merryweather.", "By them it was applied to the boilers of steam fire-engines, in which lightness and rapid steaming are of great importance.", "This was the first practical application of an internal tube within a heated one for separating the currents of hot and cold water from one another.", "The arrangement consists of an inner and outer tube\u2014the outer one, which is closed through its lower end being welded into a hemispherical shape, has its upper end expanded into the tube plate so that its exterior is exposed to the fire or hot gases; the inner tube is open at both ends and its upper end is provided with an enlarged mouthpiece, which projects above the tube plate into the water space and has three external fins supporting it centrally within the outer tube.", "The water between the two tubes, becoming heated and giving off steam, rapidly rises and is replaced by cold water which flows downward through the central tube; the enlarged mouthpiece acts as a deflector in reducing priming, and also facilitates the entry of water into the downcoming tube.", "In the Niclausse boiler and other developments of the concentric tube arrangement the rising and downcoming tubes open into separate chambers to avoid any interference between the ascending and descending currents.", "A drawing of a Field boiler (scale 1:4) shows the arrangement of the tubes."], "other": ["Inv. 1903-7, 26,268", "Inv. 1903-92"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["STOKER", "SUPERHEATER", "steam generator"], "makers": ["Mr. S. Wilcox", "Mr. G. H. Babcock"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1867", "1912"], "places": ["U.S.A."], "descriptions": ["This construction of water-tube steam generator was first patented and introduced in the U.S.A. in 1867 by Mr. S. Wilcox and Mr. G. H. Babcock, and has since undergone considerable modification and development.", "The boiler now consists of groups of straight water-tubes arranged over the grate and inclining downwards at 15 deg. into the chamber or flue beyond.", "The upper ends of these tubes open into special vertical tubes or \u201cheaders,\u201d connected above to a horizontal drum in which the steam and water rising from the tubes separate; the space within the drum above the water level acts also as the chamber or dome from which the steam is drawn off.", "The lower ends of the water tubes are similarly connected to the other end of the drum, while the lower ends of these rear headers communicate with a small transverse mud-drum serving as a mud chamber.", "These downcomers and headers allow water from the separating drum to descend to the lower ends of the tubes, to replace the water carried up as steam, or with it, thus maintaining complete circulation; and allow the solid impurities to a large extent precipitate in the mud-drum, during the downward passage of the water through the rear headers.", "The model represents a boiler having 49 inclined water-tubes, 4 in. diam. and 14 ft. long, made of wrought mild steel.", "They are expanded at each end into the headers, also of wrought mild steel, each containing one zigzag row of tubes, to accommodate which the sides of the headers are sinuous.", "For cleaning purposes these headers are provided with handholes opposite each water-tube, the handhole covers being faced metal to metal, and secured by wrought steel clamps.", "The tops of the headers are attached to the steam and water drum, 4 ft. diam., which is butt-jointed and double-riveted, by means of tubes also 4 in. diam. expanded into holes bored in pressed \u201csaddle-pieces\u201d riveted to the drum ; the front tubes are short, but the rear ones much longer on account of the inclination of the main tubes.", "The mud-drum is made of cast metal, or of wrought mild steel, and is connected to the rear headers by short expanded tubes.", "Firing is done by hand on a fixed grate or by an automatic stoker.", "The one shown is of the chain grate type embodying several improvements made by the firm.", "The travelling chains are formed of links supported on rollers and actuated by sprockets from an eccentric and ratchet from an eccentric on an overhead shaft.", "The sprockets are adjustable in channels so that it can be drawn back bodily from the furnace front. It is carried on the grate.", "The hopper is independent, being secured to the furnace front.", "It is fitted with a sliding door to regulate the depth of fuel carried on the grate.", "There is a flap which can be hooked back when it is desired to stoke by hand.", "At the far end of the grate is an ash plate with renewable nose, and beyond it a dumping door worked by worm and quadrant.", "The entire boiler is suspended, so that it can expand or contract without any strain being thrown on the surrounding brickwork, by wrought iron slings from rolled joints resting on iron columns.", "Two fire-brick baffles arranged among the tubes cause the hot gases from the furnace, under the influence of the chimney draught, to take a sinuous course which, together with the arrangement of the tubes, ensures a large amount of direct impact by the gases.", "The damper is placed in the rear wall, and the doors for cleaning the tubes and removing the soot are in the side walls, while the front is rendered accessible by two iron doors.", "The boiler is fitted with the usual mountings, comprising main steam stop-valve, safety-valve, feed-valve, blow-off valve, water gauges, and steam pressure gauge.", "The boiler represented contains about 900 sq. ft. of heating surface, which would be capable of evaporating from 3,000 to 3,500 lb. of water per hour ; such boilers can be constructed for any pressure not exceeding 500 lb. per sq. in. ; about 200 lb. is, however, the most usual.", "The model shows also the Babcock and Wilcox steam superheater as arranged in such a boiler, to heat the steam generated beyond the boiler temperature, and so reduce the subsequent losses in the steam engine.", "This superheater is placed in the space between the drum and the inclined tubes and consists of 4 groups of 6 solid drawn steel tubes 1.5 in. diam. bent into U form, arranged horizontally, and expanded at their ends into two wrought steel boxes or \u201cmanifolds,\u201d provided opposite the tubes with inspection handholes.", "The steam from the boiler drum passes down from a collecting pipe into the upper manifold, then through the superheater tubes into the lower manifold, from each end of which it passes by pipes leading to the stop-valve.", "To prevent injury to the superheater tubes when steam is being raised from a cold boiler, an arrangement is provided for flooding them with water.", "This consists of a connection with the water space of the boiler drum and two cocks, by opening the larger of which the water is admitted to the superheater but any steam formed rises directly to the boiler drum.", "When steam has been got up, before opening the boiler to the steam main, the large cock is closed and the small one is opened so that the water in the superheater drains away, a gauge glass being provided to show that the draining is completed.", "The chimney represented is 30 in. diam., by 60 ft. high, and is composed of wrought iron plates 1/8 in. thick, riveted together, and is secured to a bolted down cast iron base and is stayed by steel wire guy ropes."], "other": ["Plate VIII, No. 1.", "Inv. 1913-645, 25,534, S.M. 392."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["L\u00e9on Serpollet"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1887", "1911"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This form of steam generator, although invented many years ago, did not come into extensive use until it was taken up by L\u00e9on Serpollet in 1887, subsequently improved by him, and applied to steam carriages.", "In it superheated steam is instantaneously generated from small quantities of water pumped into heated tubes, regulation being effected by varying the quantity of water injected according to the demand for steam.", "The boiler is peculiarly suitable for motor cars, as it can be made very small for a given power, and generates steam at high pressure without being liable to danger from explosion.", "The example shown, which is from a steam car of 4.5 h.p., consists of a number of rectangular grids or coils of thick weldless steel tubing, placed horizontally, one above the other, in an asbestos lined sheet steel casing; the coils are joined in series by external coupling pipes.", "The water enters at the lower end, and the steam generated passes through all the coils, and out at the top to a throttle valve fitted with a pressure gauge.", "A paraffin burner is fitted, and this consists of a frame of tubing from which eight small nozzles project upward; a steel chimney is mounted above each nozzle, and the fuel is vaporised on its way to the nozzles by passing through a coil of tubing placed in a tray below it.", "The burner is started by burning some methylated spirit in a tray below it.", "The throttle valve is a conical disc pierced with two holes, and fitted on a conical seat through which two similar holes are drilled; a spindle attached to the valve, and passing through a stuffing-box, rotates it so as to make the holes coincide and allow the steam to pass."], "other": ["4.5 h.p.", "Inv. 1911-332"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DRAWINGS OF THERMAL STORAGE ARRANGEMENTS", "lithographs"], "makers": ["Druitt Halpin, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1902", "1891-2", "1901"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The beneficial action of a large volume of water in a steam boiler, in moderating the fluctuations in steam pressure consequent upon variations in the work being done, has long been known, while the practicability of running locomotives for moderate distances solely with the steam obtainable from a reservoir of highly heated water, has been repeatedly demonstrated on tramways and in mines. The thermal storage system employed by Mr. Halpin, while depending upon the same principles as these earlier arrangements, forms a somewhat different application. In the method he patented in 1891\u20132, which was primarily designed to overcome the difficulties experienced in electric light stations through the great variations in the work required from the plant at various times, the excess of heat received by the boilers when the engine demand for steam is slight is stored in a reservoir of hot water, suitably lagged with non-conducting covering. The reservoir is a vertical cylindrical vessel 30 ft. high by 8 ft. diam., greater capacity when necessary being secured by increasing the number of such vessels. The boiler and reservoir pressures are higher than that at which the steam is supplied to the engine, and the thermal storage is represented by the difference in the amount of heat in the reservoir at the temperatures corresponding with the higher and lower pressures respectively. With pressures of 250 lb. and 115 lb. absolute it is estimated that each pound of water originally in the reservoir will supply 0.07 lb. of steam at the lower pressure, which steam is thus available to assist the boilers at the time when the engine demand exceeds their supplying capacity; furthermore, water from the reservoir can be directly admitted to the boiler so that the feed can at the same time be shut off. When, moreover, through steam having been withdrawn, the temperature and pressure of the reservoir have fallen, the mass of cooler water it contains is capable of condensing steam from the boiler and thereby storing heat when, through a reduction in the demand, the boilers are supplying more steam than is being required. These lithographs, however, show a modification of the apparatus patented by Mr. Halpin in 1901, in which a storage reservoir or drum is placed on the top of a horizontal boiler and connected with its shell by a tube of large area which extends nearly to the top of the drum, both vessels being at the same pressure. The feed water, from an injector or pump, is introduced at the top of the drum wherein, as it becomes heated nearly to the steam pressure, it deposits its sediment thus saving incrustation in the boiler itself. This hot water, taken from above the sediment level, is afterwards allowed to flow into the boiler as feed when an exceptional load comes on, the injector feed being shut off so as to increase the steaming power. By placing the boiler and reservoir one connection within another only one opening in the shell is required.", "vertical cylindrical vessel 30 ft. high by 8 ft. diam.", "thermal storage system", "apparatus patented by Mr. Halpin in 1901", "storage reservoir or drum is placed on the top of a horizontal boiler", "feed water deposited its sediment", "heating of feed water"], "other": ["Inv. 1902-49 and 50", "The beneficial action of a large volume of water in a steam boiler, in moderating the fluctuations in steam pressure consequent upon variations in the work being done, has long been known, while the practicability of running locomotives for moderate distances solely with the steam obtainable from a reservoir of highly heated water, has been repeatedly demonstrated on tramways and in mines."]}

G. Bodmer in 1834\u201343, the fuel, while being burnt, is slowly conveyed from the front to the back of the furnace; in this way it is insured that the gases freely given off from the black coal shall pass over the glowing fuel, and so be burnt before entering the flues.", "One of these grates, 9.5 ft. long by 30 in. wide, was at work in 1843, at Old Ford, near Bow; another, 15 ft. long by 27 in. wide, was used on the Croydon Railway.", "The work was satisfactory, and smoke was prevented.", "The furnace bars are placed transversely, and are carried by two longitudinal screws between whom threads the end of the bars loosely rest.", "These screws are continuously rotated by power, and thus move the bars towards the back of the furnace, where they descend and afterwards engage with the threads of two similar screws below, which bring the bars back again to the front of the furnace, where they are automatically elevated to the grate level and again advanced.", "In the upper screws the threads are cut \" drunken \" towards the back of the furnace, so that the bars receive a rocking motion which tends to detach any clinker formed, while the lower screws have an irregularity in their pitch which separates the bars so as to allow any cinders that drop to fall between them.", "Model, scale 1:8", "Motive Power model", "furnace-grate"], "other": ["Inv. 1857-14", "S.M. 1408"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1887"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This construction of machine for feeding the fuel into the furnace and along the grate of a steam boiler was introduced in 1866 by Messrs. Vicars; it has since been extensively used and considerably modified in detail.", "The general principle of the arrangement is that the coal stored in the hopper above the furnace front is, by the aid of mechanism driven by a small steam engine or from shafting, continually being forced into the furnace front and gradually worked towards the back end of the furnace as the combustion advances; in this way continuous feeding is secured, the undue admission of air while charging is avoided, and the smoke from the \" green \" coal is compelled to pass over glowing fuel.", "The stoker is represented as fitted to the front of a Cornish boiler, the furnace flue of which has been cut out to show the arrangement of the grate.", "The fuel is stored in a large hopper above the stoker, from which it is fed by two inclined rectangular plungers, slowly reciprocated by two eccentrics on a countershaft driven by a ratchet feed from some source of power; the pawl of the ratchet acts on a projecting pin on an adjustable masking wheel, by which the attendant can regulate the supply of fuel to suit the steam demand.", "These two plungers work alternately and slowly push fuel on to as hort perforated dead plates, from which it falls on to the furnace, alternate bars of which are connected with two crossheads reciprocated horizontally by cams on the countershaft.", "The motion given to the bars is such that, although both sets move backward together, they move forward at different times; in this way the spaces between the bars are freed from clinker, and the mass of fuel is slowly worked towards the further end of the furnace, where the clinker and cinders accumulate and form a bank which acts as a fire-bridge, the excess being removed at intervals by raking it from the ash pit."], "other": ["Scale 1 : 8.", "Inv. 1877-443", "19,251", "19,260"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["James Proctor, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1888", "1875", "1888"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale 1:12.", "In this sprinkler stoker, which was originally patented by Mr. Proctor in 1875, and has since been considerably simplified and improved, the feeding is performed by a flap, which jerks the fuel on to the grate in a way resembling hand-firing with a shovel, the further distribution of the charge being accomplished by the use of reciprocating fire bars.", "The model shows the stoker fitted to the front of a Lancashire boiler, and feeding from a single coal hopper above, from which the fuel is distributed by a block, reciprocated horizontally along a pipe, to a small chamber at the front of each furnace.", "In each of these chambers is a flap which is moved away from the furnace by pegs on a revolving crank plate and then rapidly swung forward by the action of a spring, thus throwing and distributing the fuel on to the grate in small quantities.", "The fire bars are arranged in pairs alternately fixed and moving, the latter receiving a slow combined vertical and horizontal movement from a crank pin on a shaft driven by worm gearing.", "The whole of the motions are derived from a countershaft driven from an engine or by other means.", "Beneath each automatic feed hopper is a hinged flap for regulating the admission of air, and for use as a fire-door should hand-firing be resorted to."], "other": ["Inv. 1888-285", "19,252"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF CENTRE-PRESSURE STOP VALVE"], "makers": ["Messrs. J. Hopkinson & Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1907", "1903", "1906"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Scale about 1:4", "designed to lessen the strains both on the valve and seat, whilst ensuring steam tightness", "example is of the screw-down type", "with double mushroom valves", "working in opposite directions", "closing on oppositely arranged seats in the same partition", "The upper or main valve spindle is attached to a bridge piece engaging with a hollow screw-threaded sleeve of quick pitch", "The upper part of this sleeve has a thread of half the pitch, engaging with a second bridge which is supported by pillars from the valve cover and which is capable of a limited movement between collars", "The hand-wheel is fastened to the sleeve", "the spindle of the lower or controlling valve passes up through the sleeve and hand-wheel", "the lower end of the sleeve bearing on a collar on the valve spindle", "On turning the hand-wheel, the valve being shut, the upper bridge first rises until it reaches the stops; the lower bridge and the valve attached to it also rise, at double the rate during this period, owing to the pitch of the thread in the latter being double that in the former", "On continuing the rotation of the hand-wheel, the sleeve screws through the upper bridge and descends, carrying with it the lower valve spindle and opening the controlling valve; the main valve is rising at the same rate, as a result of the differential motion of the lower bridge and the sleeve", "A spring is provided to assist in returning the controlling valve to its seat", "With this type of valve it is claimed that scoring action on the faces of both valve and seat, when opening or closing, is avoided", "The controlling valve also prevents the flow of steam while the main valve is being opened or closed"], "other": ["Inv. 1907-44A"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF \u201cHOPKINSON-FERRANTI\u201d STOP VALVE"], "makers": ["Messrs. J. Hopkinson & Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1907"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this arrangement of stop valve, which was patented in 1904 by Mr. S. Z. de Ferranti, the size of the valve and the perimeter of leakage are reduced by the use of a valve of considerably less area than that of the piping, the requisite flow being obtained without excessive frictional losses by leading the fluid into the valve body by a gradually contracting vein, and then after it has passed the valve the excessive velocity energy is reconverted into pressure energy by the use of a corresponding but longer expanding orifice. The valve is of the sluice type, in two parts, one of which provides a free passage for the fluid, whilst the other contains two discs between which is a spring pressing them to the working faces to ensure steam tightness. The mechanism operating the valve is of the usual type, and consists of a hand-wheel, which can rotate only, causing a left-handed screw engaging with it and with the sluice spindle, to rise or fall, thus opening or closing the valve passage. Any tendency of the sluice to rotate is prevented by a guide attached to its spindle and sliding between pillars."], "other": ["Scale about 1:4", "Inv. 1907-44"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MASON'S REDUCING VALVE", "steam pressure reducing valve"], "makers": ["Mason Regulator Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Crosby Steam Gauge and Valve Co.", "Mason Regulator Co."], "dates": ["1910", "1886"], "places": ["U.S.A."], "descriptions": ["This is an example of the steam pressure reducing valve patented by the Mason Regulator Co., U.S.A., in 1886.", "In it the main valve is not operated directly by the steam acting on a diaphragm connected with it, as in the earlier reducing valves, but the diaphragm moves a small regulator that admits high-pressure steam behind a piston which then lifts the valve.", "The main valve is a single mushroom valve, with a flat face, held on its seat by a helical spring, and lifted by a differential piston placed below it.", "The upper side of the piston is in communication with the reduced steam, while the lower side is open to the high-pressure steam through a passage which is controlled by the regulator valve.", "The regulator is placed above the main valve, and its stem is held by a spring in contact with the diaphragm, upon the under side of which the reduced pressure acts.", "The upper side of the diaphragm is acted upon by a helical spring, the pressure of which can be adjusted to give the desired reduction.", "When steam is admitted, it passes through the regulator to the lower piston, which raises the valve high enough to give the required pressure at the outlet.", "Any variation in the pressure, on either side of the valve, disturbs the balance of the parts and causes the valve to open or close, so as to keep the outlet pressure constant.", "The valve is intended for maintaining a reduced pressure of from 5 lb. to 50 lb.", "with initial pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in., but the initial pressure must be from 10 to 15 lb. higher than the reduced pressure."], "other": ["Plate IX., No. 2", "Inv. 1910-64, S.M. 667"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Standard steam pressure reducing valve", "Motive Power valve", "valve"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["for 1\" diam. steam pipe", "in quarter section"], "other": ["Mason patent 1886"]}

Bailey & Co."], "dates": ["1903", "1896"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["arrangement of this appliance, for automatically reducing the pressure of steam or other fluid to some lower but constant pressure", "double-beat equilibrium type", "to overcome the difficulties arising from the variation in temperature of the stem connecting the two discs", "face of the upper one is nearly flat", "lower one has a very acute chamfer", "Above the valve box, but cast with it, is a circular dish separated by a flexible metallic diaphragm from a similar dish above it which is open to the atmosphere", "spindle of the valve extends upward and is attached to a cap in the centre of this diaphragm", "Above the top dish are two horizontal tie-rods, connected by crossheads, which control two helical springs under compression", "these, by short vertical levers, press upon a pair of toggle plates, which thereby exert a downward thrust upon the diaphragm and valve spindle", "boiler steam enters the space between the two valves, and rushes to the reduced pressure pipe beyond", "some, however, passes through a vertical communicating orifice to the under side of the diaphragm, which is thereby thrust upward and carrying the valve with it reduces the supply of steam, and consequently lowers the pressure below the diaphragm", "valve finds and maintains a position in which the pressure of the reduced steam on the diaphragm balances the effort exerted by the external helical springs", "By the introduction of the toggle plates the rise in the reduced pressure, which would result from the increased compression of the springs when the valve is fully opened, is prevented by the alteration that at the same time takes place in the angle of the toggle joint", "Motive Power valve"], "other": ["Inv. 1903-48", "29,807"]}

Landerhohn in 1885", "fitted with valves which automatically close and prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a glass tube breaking", "consists of two fittings attached to the boiler front and having the glass tube held between them in stuffing-boxes", "Each fitting has an internal cylindrical chamber in line with the tube, and in each of these is placed a valve which, when seated, closes the passage leading to the tube.", "valve has a long spindle passing out of the chamber through a stuffing-box and provided with a handle; the spindle carries a piston not quite as large as the chamber, so that steam and water can pass round it, but should the tube break, the rush of fluid will act upon the piston and close the valve.", "A collar on the valve spindle serves as a valve to keep the valve spindle steamtight when the valve is open, as is the case when the glass tube is intact.", "The steam pressure holds the valve to its seat.", "An overflow valve is fitted to the lower chamber.", "A sectional drawing shows the construction."], "other": ["Lent by Messrs. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["water gauge", "Motive Power gauge"], "makers": ["Dewrance & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1910"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["water gauge embodying several improvements in detail, patented by Messrs. J. Dewrance and G. H. Wall between 1888 and 1904.", "The gauge glass is held at each end by a special form of asbestos and rubber packing, held in loose glands which are enclosed and tightened up by screwed covers.", "The glands are prevented from rotating so that the asbestos being caulked by which communication is established with the steam and water spaces and overflow, are asbestos-packed (see No. 399), the asbestos being caulked into grooves surrounding the passages; they are so formed that it is impossible for the steam to blow them out.", "The stems are drawn off when the latter are un-screwed.", "The three plug cocks, for the steam to blow them out.", "The stems are drawn off when the latter are un-screwed and pass through stuffing-boxes; nuts on the ends draw them tight against the packing.", "Automatic valves are provided to prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a tube breaking.", "The one at the lower end is a simple ball valve which normally leaves a clear passage, but which would be forced up against its seat by a sudden rush of water.", "The ball can be easily removed through the front plug hole.", "The upper valve consists of a conical valve, held on its seat by the steam pressure; and having a passage through it leading to an orifice in the side of a cylindrical stem.", "A bent spring has one end opposite the orifice and is of sufficient strength to resist ordinary blowing through, but if the glass tube breaks the steam pressure would overcome the spring and force it over so to close the orifice.", "The valve is lifted out through the top plug hole when cleaning out the upper passage.", "A protecting screen of plate glass 0.5 in. thick is placed round the tube in order to minimise the danger resulting from a burst.", "special form of asbestos and rubber packing", "loose glands", "scurred covers", "plug cocks", "stuffing-boxes", "ball valve", "conical valve", "bent spring", "protecting screen of plate glass"], "other": ["Plate IX., No. 3", "Inv. 1910-56, 19,267"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["STEAM GAUGES section"], "makers": ["James Watt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Watt Collection"], "dates": ["1876"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This simple instrument may have been suggested to James Watt by the atmospheric engine, and was probably at the root of the invention of the steam engine indicator (see No. 319).", "A rocking beam with segmental ends is connected by a pitch chain at one end with the piston rod of a vertical brass cylinder 1.95 in. diam. (i.e., 3 sq. in. area), and at the other end with a helical spring.", "Connection between the condenser or other vessel, in which the degree of vacuum is to be measured, and the under side of the piston is made by means of a pipe.", "When a cock in the pipe is opened, the pressure of the atmosphere forces down the piston against the pull of the spring. The vacuum is indicated by a pointer fixed to the beam at its axis. This pointer is long compared with the beam and gives open readings on a scale which is graduated in inches of mercury."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1260", "19,636", "S.M. 833"]}

Boulton, Watt & Co., in 1808", "where the boiler pressure was 5 lb. above atmosphere", "represents the arrangement in general use till about 1850, when the continual increase in pressure led to the adoption of dial gauges", "The apparatus consists of an inverted siphon pipe of wrought iron, one extremity of which was provided with a flange for attachment to the cylinder jacket or to the steam pipe, while the other was fitted with a socket which supported a glass tube that protected a light rod terminating in a cork disc", "The siphon was half filled with mercury, so that when the steam pressure increased it caused the mercury to rise in the outer leg and so lift the rod within the glass tube, thus indicating the pressure, usually upon a scale placed behind the tube", "The tube was closed at the top, but was so fitted as not to seal the end of the siphon"], "other": ["Inv. 1899-98", "S.M. 1,055"]}

Newton, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["1918"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a gauge in which the pressure is measured by the deflection of a flat diaphragm, the deflection being magnified, and the pressure indicated by a column of fluid in a glass tube leading from the diaphragm chamber.", "The instrument consists of a cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam., made in two parts, bolted together with a thin steel plate between them.", "Steam or other fluid is admitted to the lower part of the chamber, below the diaphragm, while the upper part communicates with a glass tube 0.2 in. diam. mounted in a brass casing, on the face of which the pressure scale is engraved.", "The fluid contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the other suitable fluid, contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the pressure deflects the diaphragm and rises in the tube, the motion being magnified in the ratio of the diameter of the chamber and tube.", "The instrument must be calibrated from a standard gauge, when using the same fluid as that for which it is to be used, as allowance has to be made for the expansion of the measuring fluid when using the gauge for steam pressures."], "other": ["Inv. 1918-221", "o to 200 lb. per sq. in."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRESSURE GAUGES"], "makers": ["J. Dewrance and Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1862", "1849"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The form of pressure gauge shown was introduced in 1849 by Mons. E. Bourdon, who discovered the action upon which it relies while attempting to remove, by the application of internal pressure, the flattening caused in a pipe by bending it into a coil. When a fluid pressure was applied the pipe slightly straightened, and by fitting the free end with a pointer, found that reliable readings of the pressure were thus obtainable.", "This action depends on the fact that the product of the curvatures of a surface in planes at right angles is constant, so that if one radius of curvature is diminished, as by the elliptical section becoming more nearly circular, the other radius increases.", "The gauge consists of a thin curved tube of elliptical section, with one end fixed in a block to which the admission pipe is attached, while the other end is free; this end is closed and connected by multiplying gear with the index.", "In one of the forms shown, a link from the end of the tube is connected with a short extension of the index finger, which is pivoted near the edge of the dial.", "In the other the link is connected with a pivoted lever having a toothed sector that gears with a pinion on the axis of the index, which is mounted centrally so that the scale may extend round the whole circumference of the dial.", "Motive Power gauges"], "other": ["Inv. 1862-110"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["gauges"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRESSURE GAUGES"], "makers": ["J. Inshaw, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1862"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This arrangement of pressure gauge was patented by Mr. Inshaw in 1856.", "One of the gauges is probably the experimental instrument and has its mechanism visible, but the other is a completed boiler fitting, closed in.", "Two thin discs of sheet metal are connected at their edges so that steam or other fluid under pressure admitted into the space between the discs causes them to bulge outwards.", "Two curved levers pressing against the discs communicate motion to the index by means of a rack and pinion, the bulging of both discs being utilised.", "The action resembles that of the aneroid barometer, which is stated to have been first constructed by Vidi in 1847."], "other": ["Inv. 1862-111"]}

Rigg"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1859", "1907", "1859-60"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859.", "This instrument was designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859. Its object was to record the pressure, once in every thousand revolutions, of a beam engine driving millstones for grinding white lead.", "The instrument is connected with the engine by the shaft projecting from the front of the box, which drove a ratchet inside, operating three discs acting as cams.", "The cams revolved at different speeds, and when the notches cut in them coincided, a small lever, held in contact with the cams by a spring, fell into the depression and opened a valve, putting the indicator (the McNaught indicator (see No. 321)), into communication with the engine cylinder; the steam pipe for this connection is shown at the back of the box.", "The variations in pressure were thus admitted, then recorded, on an endless paper band, the variations in pressure for one complete revolution of the engine.", "The travel of the paper band round the drum was about 0.25 in. for every thousand revolutions of the engine, and as the engine made 18 rev. per min., the intervals of recording pressure were about 55 min. A portion of a record taken with this instrument in 1859-60 is shown.", "The recorder was also used for testing the continuity of a water supply by taking the pressure at every thousand revolutions of a water wheel temporarily arranged to drive it."], "other": ["Received 1907", "Inv. 1907-141"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Rigg's apparatus for recording engine pressure", "Rigg's apparatus for recording pressures at every 1000th stroke of in engine", "Motive Power apparatus", "apparatus"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["recording pressures at every 1000th stroke of in engine"], "other": ["Motive Power apparatus; apparatus"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRESSURE RECORDER"], "makers": ["Sir W. H. Bailey", "Mr. J. L. Norton"], "organisations/institutions": ["W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1912"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This apparatus, patented in 1868 by Sir W. H. Bailey and Mr. J. L. Norton, is designed to indicate the steam or other pressure, and also to make a continuous record showing any fluctuations that may occur.", "The recorder consists of a casing containing at the bottom an ordinary Bourdon pressure gauge, and at the top a clock.", "Between the two is placed a rotating cylinder around which is fitted a chart marked with time and pressure lines; the cylinder is rotated by the clock, and a vertically moving pen actuated by a rack and pinion from the gauge spindle, marks on the paper a line showing the pressure at any time.", "The pressure lines on the chart are uniformly spaced, but are figured to agree with the gauge readings."], "other": ["Inv. 1912-87", "S.M. 1245"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Pressure recorder"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1868"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["An instrument for recording pressure.", "This instrument recorded pressure by means of a pen drawing a line on a rotating drum."], "other": ["SMG 1245", "SMG 1912-87"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["in addition to the ordinary indication of the actual pressure, it is made to indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded in the working of the apparatus to which the gauge is fixed, and also the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded. The latter object is effected by a short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained. The number of times that a given pressure has been exceeded is recorded by three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels."], "other": ["Inv. 1874-140"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["pressure gauge"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Motive Power"], "other": ["G.A. Everett"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1921"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument, of the Bourdon type, produces a continuous record of the varying pressures maintained during a period of 24 hours in a steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant; irregularities in working can thus be detected. A reservoir pen on the end of the pointer which is connected by a link to the Bourdon tube works one revolution in the 24 hours. To facilitate the removal of the chart the pen arm is jointed, and can be raised by means of a knurled adjusting screw. The dial is 8 in. diam., and pressures up to 120 lb. per sq. in. can be recorded.", "Bourdon type", "continuous record of the varying pressures", "steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant", "detecting irregularities in working", "pen arm is jointed, and can be raised by means of a knurled adjusting screw"], "other": ["Inv. 1921-729"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["\"THERMOFEED\" REGULATOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Ronald Trist & Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914", "1911"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["sectioned example of the device", "patented by Mr. A. R. Trist", "for regulating automatically the quantity of feed-water delivered to a boiler so as to maintain a constant water level.", "Waste of fuel, due to incorrect or large variations in level which occur with hand-feed regulation, are thus avoided.", "The apparatus consists of two parts, a float chamber and a regulator.", "The float chamber is a cast-iron vessel connected near the top with the steam space of the boiler, well above the water level, and at the bottom with the water space well below the water level.", "Within this vessel is an electrolytically sealed copper float connected by toggle levers with a vertical spindle, carrying at its upper end a two-faced controlling valve which rests on either of two seatings formed on the opposite faces of a gunmetal block.", "The valve seat and toggle levers are attached to a long sleeve passing through the cover of the float chamber, the sleeve being screwed for part of its length which passes through a nut, by which its height can be adjusted so as to set the water level at any desired point.", "Steam is led from the underside of the controlling valve seating block through radial holes with a pipe leading to the regulator.", "The upper part of the regulator is open to the atmosphere.", "The regulator consists of a gunmetal feed valve with a piston working in a cylinder above it.", "The upper part of the cylinder is connected with the pipe from the controlling valve, while its lower end is open to the atmosphere.", "The feed valve is normally held open by a spring, acting through a lever, and is pressed down to close it when steam is admitted to the cylinder.", "If the water level rises, the float is lifted and the controlling valve is lowered by the toggle levers until it rests on its upper seat.", "Steam can then pass from the float chamber to the regulator cylinder so as to force down the piston and close the feed valve.", "When the water level falls, the controlling valve is raised on to its lower seat, steam is cut off from the regulator and its cylinder is exhausted to the atmosphere, so that the spring comes into action and re-opens the feed valve.", "The steam connection between the controlling valve and the regulator is fitted with a double-seated valve, which in one position permits steam to pass to the regulator, but in the other position shuts off the steam and permanently puts the regulator to atmosphere, so that the latter may be put out of action if desired.", "In case of puncture of the float or breakage of the mechanism, the feed valve will remain wide open, so that there will be no risk of shortness of water.", "It is claimed that the water level can be maintained within 0.125 in. of correct level with ordinary boilers, or within 0.25 in. with water-tube boilers."], "other": ["Mr. A. R. Trist", "Inv. 1914-192.", "2 in. diam. feed pipe"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF OIL SEPARATOR"], "makers": ["Messrs. Bakers (Leeds), Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1902 onwards"], "places": ["Leeds"], "descriptions": ["Scale about 1:4", "The trouble brought about by the presence of grease in boiler feed water is well known, but the loss of efficiency in feed heaters, etc., owing to the deposition of oil carried forward by exhaust steam has not been so widely recognised.", "mechanical separator", "The separator is most conveniently made, as shown, cylindrical in form, with the inlet and outlet branches arranged to suit its position.", "The exhaust steam carrying oil and water in suspension enters an expansion compartment, where reduction of velocity and temperature takes place, allowing the water and oil to coalesce into drops that impinge on the sides and on the surface of water, filling the lower part of the vessel 3 to 6 in. in depth.", "The steam passes under a deflector or baffle into the second compartment, where it impinges on vertical angles of special section staggered in rows.", "The oil and water so arrested trickle down these collectors by gravity and float off at the grease off-take, which is provided on the shell behind these collectors.", "It is claimed that the apparatus is thus self-cleansing.", "A drain on the bottom cover is provided for periodical blow-off purposes.", "A set of water-gauges is fitted to indicate the water-level.", "The apparatus is applicable also for other purposes, such as the extraction of tar from fuel gas."], "other": ["Mr. W. J. Baker", "1921"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Oil Separator Model"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1921"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A model of an oil separator, demonstrating a mechanical method for removing oil from exhaust steam.", "The device features an inlet and outlet for steam, and an internal mechanism designed to coalesce and remove oil and water.", "The separator aims to improve the efficiency of steam-powered systems by preventing oil contamination in feed water.", "The patent for this type of separator was granted in 1902.", "The apparatus is made in a variety of sizes."], "other": ["SMG 1921-657"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MODEL OF AIR HEATER"], "makers": ["S. Utting, Esq., M.I.Mech.E.", "Monsieur Emile Prat"], "organisations/institutions": ["Etablissements Emile Prat-Daniel"], "dates": ["1921", "1920"], "places": ["Paris"], "descriptions": ["Scale about 1:4.", "The object of this heater, known as the \u201cThermix,\u201d is to utilise the sensible heat in flue gases from boiler and industrial furnaces.", "The apparatus is placed in the waste gases flue from a boiler or furnace.", "The features of the heater are the simplicity of design and the ease with which worn-out parts can be replaced; it consists of a frame built up of rolled steel, containing plain flat plates of steel about 3 mm. thick, superposed with distance pieces and coils of steel wire between each, the object of the latter being to transmit pressure uniformly along the edges of the plates and so ensure tight joints.", "Alternate cells thus formed are in communication with the flue gases and with the cold air respectively.", "While the former have a straight run the latter has a course transverse to the waste gases in the shape of the letter U, as indicated by the arrows on the model; this U-shaped course is ensured by inserting a series of diaphragms.", "The air is circulating usually by means of a centrifugal fan.", "The heated air is used for various purposes, such as the supply of boiler furnaces, heating and drying materials, etc."], "other": ["Lent by", "Inv. 1921-441."]}

Temperatures from 100\u00b0 F. to 950\u00b0 F. can be recorded."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["CARBON DIOXIDE THERMOSCOPE"], "makers": ["Mr. B. C. Hinman"], "organisations/institutions": ["The Underfeed Stoker Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1914", "1908"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a portable instrument, patented in 1908 by Mr. B. C. Hinman, for measuring the percentage of carbon dioxide (CO\u2082) in flue gases, and is thus of use for checking and improving plant efficiency.", "In principle it makes use of the reaction between carbon dioxide and caustic soda.", "A hand-operated plunger working in a pump barrel draws a sample of the gas mixture from the flue through a three-way cock and rubber connection.", "This gas is allowed to fall to the temperature of the room, which may be read on a thermometer enclosed in the pump rod.", "The lower end of the pump rod is graduated with a scale marked in degrees of temperature, and by drawing the plunger out to the graduation corresponding to the room temperature, the correct amount of gas is used.", "A small cylindrical cartridge, containing a definite quantity of pulverised caustic soda, is packed at both ends and inserted in a receptacle in the instrument, where it is surrounded by the bell-shaped bulb of a thermometer which fits closely round it.", "This thermometer reads against an adjustable scale graduated in percentages of carbon dioxide, the scale being set to zero before the instrument is used.", "Having taken the sample of gas, the rubber tube is connected to a hard rubber plug beneath the cartridge and the plunger depressed.", "The gas is driven through the cartridge and the rise in temperature reads directly as a percentage of carbon dioxide."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-223", "S.M. 645", "thermometer", "scale", "plunger", "pump barrel", "three-way cock", "rubber connection", "caustic soda", "cartridge", "thermometer bulb", "adjustable scale"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["FEED-WATER HEATER"], "makers": ["Messrs. Joseph Wright & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901", "1871\u20136"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this heater, which was patented by Mr. R. Berryman in 1871\u20136, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers.", "The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals.", "Beneath this shell is the middle belt, into which the steam enters on one side and, after passing through the tubes, is condensed into water which collects in the base.", "The base is divided by a diaphragm, which also supports the tube plate and has openings below through which any remaining steam can pass away; the collected water is discharged by a siphon when it exceeds a certain depth.", "Motive Power model"], "other": ["Scale 1:8", "Inv. 1901-39"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Model", "Berryman type feed water heater Model", "model"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["in separate pieces"], "other": ["Scale 1:8"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["FEED-WATER HEATER"], "makers": ["James Atkinson"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this feed-water heater, patented by Mr. J. Atkinson in 1877, the exhaust steam from the engine enters at the steam inlet and passes in a direct unimpeded course through a channel provided for it, which is of a similar sectional area throughout, to the steam outlet, from which the exhaust pipe conducts away the steam not utilised in heating the water.\nThe channel is open at the top to the lower side of the tube plate. Screwed into the tube plate are a number of vertical tubes, open to the exhaust steam at the bottom, but closed at their upper ends, which are left perfectly free to expand or contract without straining. In each of these heating tubes is a small circulating tube leading from near their upper ends to the channel through which the exhaust steam passes, and the mouths are so arranged that the passing steam causes an induced current out of them, and thus out of the upper ends of the heating tubes, removing the air which they contain, or which may be carried in with the exhaust steam, and causing them to be filled with steam. A small portion of the heating tubes projects into the exhaust steam, and assists in diverting the steam into them."], "other": ["Inv. 1890-107"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["STEAM PUMP"], "makers": ["J. Cameron, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This type of direct-acting flywheel donkey pump was patented by Mr. Cameron in 1852, and has since been extensively adopted for boiler feeding and similar work.", "The steam cylinder is arranged vertically over the pump barrel, and the pump rod is attached to an inverted kite-shaped casting which terminates in the pump plunger; within the loop of this casting is arranged a connecting rod, attached to it and to the overhanging crank of a flywheel shaft, so that direct action is secured while the control of a crank and flywheel is retained.", "The slide valve is worked by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the other end of this shaft is provided with another crank working a similar single-acting pump; the cranks are set opposite, so that the pumps deliver alternately.", "Sometimes double-acting pumps are substituted, while very frequently there are two steam cylinders in the arrangement shown.", "The pump valve bores are formed in the supporting columns which act as air vessels."], "other": ["Inv. 1887-131"]}
