Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM MODEL OF PETROL MOTOR (working)"], "makers": ["Made in the Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum"], "dates": ["1912"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This model is designed to show the operation of a petrol motor (see No. 516) working on the \"Otto\" or four-stroke cycle.", "A revolving pointer indicates the suction or first stroke and the points in the stroke at which the valves open and close, while another pointer moves over a power diagram such as would be obtained by an indicator attached to the cylinder.", "The four-stroke cycle\u2014so called because there is one working stroke in every four strokes\u2014is used in most of the internal combustion engines of to-day.", "The efficiency of the cycle depends upon the compression of the gaseous mixture before ignition, which gives a high initial pressure and a large tempera-ture range.", "External pumps were avoided, and the engine simplified, by making the engine single-acting and by using the cylinder alternately as a power cylinder and a pump; a heavy fly-wheel was provided to store enough energy to perform the pumping stroke.", "During the first outward stroke of the cycle the inlet valve opens and the piston draws in a cylinder-full of petrol vapour and air; the inlet valve then closes, and in the second or return stroke the mixture is compressed into the clearance space left at the back end of the cylinder. At the commencement of the second out-stroke the compressed charge is fired by an electric spark, the resulting high pressure driving the piston through this third stroke and storing much energy in the fly-wheel; near the end of this stroke the exhaust valve opens and remains open during the return or fourth stroke, by which the products of combustion are delivered through the exhaust pipe to the atmos-phere. The exhaust valve then closes, and a fresh cycle commences with the next out-stroke.", "Petrol motors are now usually governed by throttling the incoming charge, thus reducing the compression and power, but at the same time reducing the efficiency."], "other": ["Inv. 1912-122"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["The Four-stroke Cycle of a Petrol Motor"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1912"], "places": ["London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom", "England", "Science Museum"], "descriptions": ["Moving diagram model, scale 1:2, four-stroke cycle petrol motor, with cycle indicator and power diagram, in frame on two legs", "Heat Engines (non steam) models; diagrammatic models; models; diagrammatic models"], "other": ["scale 1:2"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PETROL MOTOR WITH MAGNETO \u2013 ELECTRIC IGNITION (working)"], "makers": ["Simms Manufacturing Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Daimler-Maybach", "R. Bosch", "F. R. Simms"], "dates": ["1905", "1897\u201398"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["high-speed internal combustion engine", "working on the Otto four-stroke cycle", "using petrol as fuel", "designed for use on motor-cars and launches, or for industrial purposes", "one single-acting cylinder 95 mm. (3.74 in.) diam. by 110 mm. (4.33 in.) stroke", "develops 5 h.p. when running at its normal speed of 1,000 rev. per min., but may develop 6 h.p. when accelerated", "cylinder is cast in one piece with its head, valve chamber, and water-jacket", "mounted vertically over a closed aluminium chamber supporting the crankshaft in bearings at each end", "carrying at one side a cam shaft driven by toothed wheels, at half the speed of the crankshaft", "elongated piston is packed with three spring rings", "connecting rod is attached by a pin passing through it", "crankshaft is balanced and carried on one end through a heavy fly-wheel whose coned interior forms one member of a friction clutch through which the power is transmitted", "Wings formed on the crank chamber support the engine from a suitable framework", "valve chamber is divided by a horizontal partition in which are formed two seats for the inlet and exhaust valves, the port leading to the cylinder being above it", "valves are of steel and their spindles extend downward through the bottom of the chamber to meet the cam rods which operate them, springs being provided to return the valves to their seats", "Below the valves the chamber is divided vertically, one side being the inlet and the other the exhaust", "valves are easily removed after taking out a screwed plug above them and a cotter in the spindle", "Petroleum spirit or petrol, a mixture of light hydro-carbons obtained by the distillation of crude petroleum and having a sp. gr. of 0.7 to 0.76, is used in preference to the heavier and cheaper oils chiefly on account of its easy vaporisation, certainty of ignition, and small residue.", "explosive mixture, consisting of 1 vol. of petrol vapour and 17\u201320 vols. of air, is prepared in a float-feed carburetter of the Daimler-Maybach type.", "consists of a chamber attached to the inlet pipe of the engine having in the centre a fine vertical nozzle; the nozzle communicates with a larger chamber containing a float which actuates, by weighted levers, a needle valve so as to keep the petrol at a constant height in the nozzle.", "During the suction stroke of the piston air is drawn in round the nozzle through adjustable openings and draws off the petrol, which is vaporised and mixed with it in a fairly constant proportion.", "petrol enters at the bottom of the float chamber through a gauze strainer.", "ignition of the mixture is performed by a low tension spark, the current being supplied by a magneto-electric machine of the form patented by Messrs. R. Bosch and F. R. Simms in 1897\u201398.", "consists of a permanent com- pound horseshoe magnet fixed vertically on a non-magnetic bedplate and having an armature of H section fixed between its poles; one end of the armature winding is attached to an insulated terminal and the other to the core itself, thus being in metallic connection with the cylinder.", "In the air gap between the armature and poles an iron shield is placed, consisting of two segments, connected at the ends and provided with pivots; this is oscillated by a rod from a crankpin in the sparking cam fixed to the half-speed shaft, thus varying the magnetic flux through the armature coil and generating a current.", "spark is produced by a contact breaker consisting of an insulated pin projecting into the combustion chamber and a spindle carrying an interrupter arm which is normally held in contact with the pin by a spring acting on an external lever, but is knocked off by a tappet rod raised by the cam and returned by a spring.", "circuit is completed through the cylinder and casing.", "time of ignition can be varied by a lever which pulls over the lower end of the tappet rod.", "speed of the engine is regulated by a centrifugal governor which operates a butter- fly valve placed in the inlet pipe, so throttling the mixture and reducing the compression.", "When extra power is required the governor may be put out of action and the engine allowed to race.", "cylinder and valve box are cooled by a water-jacket surrounding them.", "Lubricant is supplied to the crank chamber to be distributed by the splashing of the crank.", "engine is started by a movable winch handle engaging with a pin on the shaft, a cock on the cylinder head being opened to reduce the com- pression, which is normally 70 lb. per sq. in.", "petrol consumption of such motors varies from 0.8 to 1.6 pints per brake h.p. hour."], "other": ["Inv. 1905-45, 29,207", "Total weight of the motor is 186 lb.", "5 h.p.", "6 h.p.", "1,000 rev. per min."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is an example of the two-stroke valveless motor patented by Mr. J. Day in 1891. It operates on the Clerk cycle (see No. 502) but has no inlet or exhaust valve, the piston itself serving as a valve when passing over three ports formed in the cylinder wall.", "The engine has a single vertical cylinder 3.25 in. diam. by 3.25 in. stroke and develops 2.5 h.p. when running at 900 rev. per min., and is bolted to a cylindrical crank in one piece with its head and water-jacket, and is bolted to a cylindrical crank chamber provided with supporting wings.", "The ends of the crank chamber are closed by dished covers which reduce its volume, and carry long solid crank- shaft bearings which are lined with white metal and lubricated with grease so as to be airtight.", "The ascent of the piston causes a partial vacuum in the crank chamber, and when near the top of its stroke its lower edge uncovers a port communicating with the carburetter, and thus permits the mixture of air and petrol to rush into the crank chamber to a pressure of 3 or 4 lb. per sq. in.; the piston then com- presses the charge in the crank chamber due to the descent of its stroke and when near the bottom of its stroke its upper edge first uncovers the exhaust port and next the inlet port which communicates with the crank chamber, so that the products of combustion are expelled and the fresh charge introduced during a very short period. The charge is compressed on the next up-stroke and fired by an electric spark.", "A projecting lip on the piston deflects the entering mixture upwards to prevent it from passing directly to the exhaust port, but there is an appreciable loss in this way, especially at low speeds. For this reason, and on account of the difficulty of getting the charge in and out of the cylinder in the short time available, this type of engine does not give double the power of a four-stroke engine of the same size, but only about 50 per cent. more at the normal speed, and even less at higher speeds.", "The mean effective pressure is about 60 lb. per sq. in.", "A specially compact form of spray carburetter, having a hand-adjusted needle jet, is attached to the crank chamber inlet port, and this is provided with a non-return valve.", "A heavy fly-wheel is fitted to one end of the crank-shaft and the ignition contact maker is placed behind it; a long lever is pro-vided for varying the point of ignition."], "other": ["VALVELESS TWO-STROKE PETROL MOTOR.", "Inv. 1913-164, S.M. 441.", "The engine can be run with paraffin if fitted with a suitable carburetter, and it will run equally well in either direction.", "It weighs, complete, 70 lb.", "Presented by the Day Motor Co., Ltd."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["seven-figure engine revolution counter", "reciprocating counter"], "makers": ["T. R. and T. W. Harding"], "organisations/institutions": ["Messrs. Harding, Rhodes & Co., Ltd."], "dates": ["1919", "1881"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["seven-figure engine revolution counter of the form patented by Messrs. T. R. and T. W. Harding in 1881", "The indelible black figures are carried on seven white, porcelain-faced drums, placed side by side on a shaft extending across the casing.", "Behind the drums is placed the driving shaft, which projects at both ends and carries on one end an arm which is connected with some reciprocating part of the engine.", "This shaft carries, within the casing at the right hand end, an escapement lever which by its rocking motion rotates a three-tooth pinion; this pinion engages with teeth on the first number drum and causes it to move round through one-twentieth of a turn for each stroke of the engine, or one-tenth of a turn per revolution.", "Each number drum has 20 pin teeth on its right side and two teeth at one point on the left side.", "Above the drums is mounted a long countershaft, on which six pinions revolve loosely and project into the spaces between the drums.", "Each pinion has eight teeth engaging with the 20-toothed ring on its left, and at intervals with the two teeth on the adjacent drum, so that when the ten figure of the first drum comes in sight, the two teeth on that drum rotate the first pinion a quarter turn, and the pinion transmits the motion to the second drum, causing it turn through one-tenth of a revolution, and so on through the series.", "In order to hold the drums stationary between their movements, the alternate teeth are removed from the right-hand edge of each pinion, and two adjacent remaining teeth bear on the surface of a plain part of the rim of the drum, so that the pinion cannot turn until a notch in this plain part, corresponding with the space between the two teeth of the drum, comes opposite to the pinion.", "The counter is contained in a rectangular case of polished brass, the front of which can be opened only by means of a special screw key.", "The figures on the drums are arranged to come close up to the glass front of the case."], "other": ["Presented by Messrs. Harding, Rhodes & Co., Ltd.", "Inv. 1919-401"]}
